headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Welcome to The Macerich Company Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I'd like to remind everyone that this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Jean Wood, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everyone, for joining us today on our fourth quarter 2015 earnings call. During the course of this call, management may make certain statements that may be deemed forward-looking within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities L
componenttext:
Thank you, everyone, for joining us today on our fourth quarter 2015 earnings call. During the course of this call, management may make certain statements that may be deemed forward-looking within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. We refer you to today's press release and our SEC filings for a detailed discussion of forward-looking statements. 
Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the earnings release and the supplemental filed on Form 8-K with the SEC. These are posted in the Investors section of the company's website at www.macerich.com. 
Joining us today are Art Coppola, CEO and Chairman; Tom O'Hern, Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Robert Perlmutter, Executive Vice President, Leasing; John Perry, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Tom.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jean. Consistent with past practice, we'll be limiting the call to 1 hour. If we run out of time and you still have questions, please do not hesitate to call me or John Perry or Jean. The fourth quarter reflected continued operational excelle
componenttext:
Thank you, Jean. Consistent with past practice, we'll be limiting the call to 1 hour. If we run out of time and you still have questions, please do not hesitate to call me or John Perry or Jean. 
The fourth quarter reflected continued operational excellence as evidenced by the strength of our key operating metrics. We saw the successful completion of our joint venture strategy, the completion of a number of highly attractive financings, the reinvestment of capital into our best assets through redevelopment and share buybacks. We'll talk about these in greater detail later in the call. 
We continue to see very significant benefit from our efforts in 2012 through 2015 to sell noncore, slower-growing assets and redeploying that capital into higher-quality, more productive assets. 
Looking at the leasing activity. We did volume in the fourth quarter, we signed leases under 10,000 square feet. We had 313,000 square feet signed. Positive re-leasing spread on a trailing 12-month basis of 14.2%. 
Looking at mall occupancy. It came in at 96.1%, up 30 basis points from 12/31 of '14, above [ph] 70 basis points from our occupancy level at the end of the third quarter. Average mall store base rents also increased to 54 32 up from 51 15 a year ago. 
FFO for the quarter came in at $1.12. That compared to $0.99 for the quarter-end December 31, 2014. Same-center NOI increased by 6.4% in the quarter. And year-to-date NOI -- same-center NOI growth was a sector-leading 6.5%. This increase was driven by increased occupancy, double-digit re-leasing spreads, annual rent increases and aggressive operating cost management. 
Looking at the gross margin at the centers. It improved to 71% for the quarter, up from 68.6% in the fourth quarter last year. Looking at the year-to-date, margin improved by 250 basis points to 69.3% compared to 66.8% for the full year 2014. 
Bad debt expense for the quarter was up slightly at $1 million, comparing to $800,000 in the fourth quarter last year. The average interest rate, 3.6%, was slightly higher than the 3.48% average rate at the end of 2014. 
The balance sheet continues to be in great shape. At quarter-end, looking at the key balance sheet metrics, debt-to-market cap was 34%. Interest coverage ratio was a very strong 4.0x. Debt to EBITDA on a forward basis, 7.2x. The average debt maturity, and this is after the Arrowhead financing and the closing of the joint venture to 6 years, up significantly from a few years ago. We did a total of about $3 billion in financing in 2015. And within the past quarter, we did $1.8 billion. It included Arrowhead 12-year loan, $400 million at 4.05%; los Cerritos, another 12-year loan at 4%; Washington Square, $550 million loan, 3.65%, 7 years; South Plains, Twenty Ninth Street, also refinanced. So that was $1.825 billion in financings. Average tenure of 10.1 years and average interest rate of 3.94%. 
In mid-November, we set about to execute on our $1.2 billion of approved share buyback. We engaged an investment bank to do a $400 million accelerated stock repurchase program. At the beginning of that program, we received and retired 4.1 million shares, when the plan started, which was November 13, and the balance of the shares were to be delivered based on the average daily volume adjusted price of MAC during the buying period, less negotiated discount. 
On January 20, 2016, the ASR program was completed. Effectively, MAC bought back $400 million worth of shares at $78.26. We received another 971,000 shares at that time. So this program, the first ASR under the $1.2 billion program, retired a total of 5.1 million shares. 
Also, since the last call, we had 2 special dividends that resulted from the joint venture transactions. They were each up $2. One was paid in December and one in January. 
In our press release this morning, we provide 2016 FFO per share guidance. The range was $4.05 to $4.15. The guidance assumptions included same-center NOI growth of 4.5% to 5%, which is very significant given that 2015 is a tough comparison year at [indiscernible] coming in at 6.5%. The acquisition and guidance includes a $330 million of our share of Country Club Plaza, which has been previously announced. It also reflects roughly $1 billion of dispositions, which relates to the joint venture interests that we closed in January with Heitmann and GIC. 
The other assumptions are included in the 8-K supplement filed last night. Our NOI guidance for 2016 is consistent with the guidance we gave in early 2015 after adjusting for the impact of the joint ventures. 
At this point, I'd like to turn it over to Bobby to discuss the leasing environment.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. The leasing activity in the fourth quarter remained, strong reflecting the high-quality nature of the company shopping centers. Occupancy increased to 96.1%, which represented a 30 basis point year-over-year increase. Permanent occupancy ende
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. The leasing activity in the fourth quarter remained, strong reflecting the high-quality nature of the company shopping centers. Occupancy increased to 96.1%, which represented a 30 basis point year-over-year increase. Permanent occupancy ended the year at 90.5%. Temporary Occupancy increased to 5.6%, which reflects the bankruptcies incurred at the end of 2014 and the beginning of 2015. During 2015, a total of 250,000 square feet was converted from temporary to permanent occupancy. 
Leasing spreads were 14.2%, again indicating strong demand for space in the portfolio. Leasing spreads were strongest in the East and West Coast centers. Average rent for leases signed in 2015 was $57.41 per square foot. This represented a 5.4% increase over the prior year. 
During the year, we signed leases for approximately 4 million square feet, which was a 2.4% increase over 2014. The average lease term for leases signed in 2015 was 6.2 years. 
Portfolio of sales increased by 8.2% year-over-year to $635 per square foot. Comparable-center sales increased by 7.6% year-over-year. Sales increases were highest in the West Coast and Arizona centers. And during 2015, sales were positively impacted by: one, high-volume tenants; two, strong categories such as home furnishing, jewelry, cosmetics and athletic footwear; three, organic growth from merchants with strong brands; and four, store closures of underproductive tenants. 
Tourism. While our portfolio only has moderate exposure to international tourists and luxury business, we have seen certain centers impacted by tourism and the stronger U.S. dollar. Most notable in our portfolio is Fashion Outlets in Niagara Falls, whose sales have been impacted by the steep decline in the Canadian dollar. 
Holiday sales. Most retailers are indicating holiday sales were in line with our expectations. Black Friday sales have been distributed over most of the week, starting with pre-Thanksgiving sales. Retailers are also reporting the last few days before Christmas as well as the post-Christmas activity was stronger than expected. Many retailers were promotional throughout the entire season. We believe this is likely to increase the strain on those stores under financial pressure. In general, it appears that specialty stores fared better than department stores during the holiday season. 
2014 and 2015 bankruptcies. As we discussed during the third quarter earnings call, we expect bankruptcies and rent relief requests in 2016 to be at similar or higher levels than in 2015. This is reflected in our 2016 forecast. We believe many of these retailers are likely to restructure and reduce the number of locations within their plate as opposed to liquidate the entire chain. This is likely to impact lower-productivity centers to a greater degree. 
During 2014 and 2015, there were 11 major store closings or bankruptcies that impacted 134 stores or 413,000 square feet within our portfolio. The average rent for these stores was $54 per square foot. They generated sales of $241 per square foot and had an occupancy cost of 22.6%. As of 12/31/15, 66% of the space has been re-leased, resulting in a significant upgrade to the merchandise mix, improved sales productivity and a rent spread in the high single digits. 
E-commerce. We are continuing to learn how retailers use their brick-and-mortar stores as a key component to support growth in their e-commerce sales. A number of important trends are emerging. One, the brick-and-mortar stores are integral to the e-commerce efforts. Two, focus, bought online, pick up in stores is becoming increasingly important to retailers; three, online sales have a high percentage of returns, especially on apparel; four, physical store sales are reduced by online returns, which reduces reported sales for brick-and-mortar locations; five, the customers enter the mall equipped with more information from the web than ever before; six, pure e-tailers are migrating to brick-and-mortar stores, generating new leasing opportunities; and seven, physical store presence improves online sales. These trends are supported by recent customer research conducted at a cross-section of Macerich centers. The research indicated that lower average expenditures and shorter-term durations were more than offset by increased frequency of visits and higher conversion rates. We firmly believe that stores located in densely populated trade areas will benefit the most and increase in importance to the retailer. 
Big boxes. Throughout the portfolio, there is strong demand for big box users larger than 10,000 square feet. We've increased our exposure with retailers such as TJ Maxx, Home Goods, [indiscernible] Nordstrom Rack. These retailers have opened stores across the portfolio, including closed centers, open-air centers as well as lower-productivity centers. 
In addition, during the fourth quarter, we signed a lease with JCPenney at inland center to open in the former [indiscernible] building. JCPenney is on track for an opening in the fourth quarter of 2016. 
We continue to devote additional resources to activate the common areas of our centers. Efforts are orientated towards permanent kiosks and business development opportunities as well as incubation of online retailers into physical stores. Multiple goals for the common area include revenue enhancement, improved presentation and an elevated customer experience. 
Development. Leasing at the development projects remains on track. At Broadway Plaza, we have 87% of expansion space under executed leases. We are very pleased with the merchandise mix and eager for the majority of expansion to open during the second quarter of 2016. This will add to our existing anchors of Nordstrom, Macy's and Neiman Marcus. 
At Green Acres, anchored by Dick's -- at Green Acres Commons, anchored by Dick's Sporting Goods, we have 85% of the space under executed leases and are anticipating third quarter opening in 2016. 
Finally, we've completed the public financing agreements and are moving forward with the development of Fashion Outlets at Philadelphia, in partnership with [indiscernible] This project is anticipated to be completed in late 2018 or early 2019 and will incorporate approximately 775,000 square feet of retail area. 
With that, I'd like to turn it over to Art.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bobby. Thanks, Tom. That's a lot to cover. So I'm going to cover just a few other items, and then we'll open it up to Q&A. As you can see, our operating results were terrific on every level, whether it be margin improvement, occupancy levels,
componenttext:
Thank you, Bobby. Thanks, Tom. That's a lot to cover. So I'm going to cover just a few other items, and then we'll open it up to Q&A. 
As you can see, our operating results were terrific on every level, whether it be margin improvement, occupancy levels, rents that we have in place in the portfolio, re-leasing spreads. All of these are factors that contributed to a very significant same-center NOI growth rate in 2015 and gives us optimism into the future as to our growth patterns over the next couple of years. It's hard to predict what's going to happen, obviously, in the retail broader environment. And there are many factors that can influence that up or down. But we recognize that if you think about all of the different levers that we can pull, that can create shareholder value, that there probably is no lever more important than having the maximum possible same-center NOI growth pattern. Developments, redevelopments, these are also extremely value creation, but they obviously have capital that gets deployed as part of that process. It is a permanent lever that we will be pulling in the redevelopment arena or the new development arena. And we've got a very strong track record of positive results from those activities, and we anticipate that the projects that are underway right now will continue to drive value for us going forward. 
Another lever that we didn't anticipate that we were going to be able to pull, that would -- that gave us the opportunity, we feel, to create value here was the selected disposition of a noncore asset, a mall in November this past year. And the agreement with Macerich and Taubman to purchase Country Club Plaza in Kansas City from Highwood Properties. That closing is anticipated to close March 1. The gross price is $660 million with a 50% anticipated loan to value that we would anticipate will be put on the property. Most all of our equity will be funded through the -- disposition proceeds that we generated from Panorama. Country Club Plaza is an iconic, 15-block, 1.3-million square-foot mixed-use retail and office property located in the heart of Kansas City. It is well known throughout the industry, and we believe that jointly, with Taubman, we will be successful in taking that property up to an even higher level of performance than where it is right now. We are very pleased to have completed the joint ventures that we did. That was a very significant and large capital decision or capital recycling decision and to effectively have raised new capital in the private markets through joint ventures, that was used to fund either -- both the special dividend that we paid out as well as to fund the stock buyback program that we've announced. And we're pleased that just a couple of months after announcing the $1.2 billion authorization that we've got over 1/3 -- we got about 1/3 of that has been accomplished and delivered to date. So we're very happy about that. 
The status and the new developments. I think we're in very good shape there. If you take a look at Philadelphia, the redevelopment of Broadway Plaza, the addition of the theater to Santa Monica Place, the expansion of Green Acres and the recycling of the Sears Building ultimately at Kings Plaza and Fashion Outlets of San Francisco, we think we're in a very good position through those projects to deliver good shareholder value into the future. But again, I would reiterate that, obviously, in a risk-adjusted basis, we see the opportunity to generate strong same-center NOI growth as being one of the most attractive levers that we can pull in creating shareholder value. 
So with that, operator, I'd like to open it up for Q&A.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Craig Schmidt with Bank of America.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Craig Schmidt with Bank of America.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: In thinking about comping against the tougher same-store NOIs, how much of a room do you have against these aggressive operating cost management?
componenttext: In thinking about comping against the tougher same-store NOIs, how much of a room do you have against these aggressive operating cost management?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Craig, so that will fall into 2016. We really set out to do that in the second quarter. So we'll probably have a quarter and a half of that which will positively benefit 2016. We really pretty aggressively manage those. We'll continue to do that, but I do
componenttext: Craig, so that will fall into 2016. We really set out to do that in the second quarter. So we'll probably have a quarter and a half of that which will positively benefit 2016. We really pretty aggressively manage those. We'll continue to do that, but I don't think we'll see the same kind of cuts in 2016 as we had in 2015. So it's hard to duplicate. I think we can maintain what we did, but it's going to be hard to replicate the same amount.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then -- and when thinking about possibly selling some more of your noncore assets, how many more assets would you like to sell out of the portfolio?
componenttext: And then -- and when thinking about possibly selling some more of your noncore assets, how many more assets would you like to sell out of the portfolio?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really don't have a number per se. It's really opportunistic at this point. We really have taken the portfolio in terms of its composition to where we wanted to get it, with well over 95% of our NOI being fortress-type of income. So anything that we do
componenttext: We really don't have a number per se. It's really opportunistic at this point. We really have taken the portfolio in terms of its composition to where we wanted to get it, with well over 95% of our NOI being fortress-type of income. So anything that we do going forward, the way that we think about it is that dispositions will be there as a source of capital for us over the next, say, 3 to 5 years, to fund opportunities, whether they be development, redevelopment or potentially even an acquisition of something. So there is no specific number, but we clearly do intend to periodically continue to prune the portfolio and to recycle the capital, funding the purchase of a great center like Country Club Plaza, with the disposition of a very mature, kind of enclosed community center equity source of capital is really, from my viewpoint, a great trade for the company. And likewise, funding development and redevelopment capital going forward through selling off noncore assets is also, to me, a very sensible thing to do.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, we have a question from Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And next, we have a question from Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 quick leasing questions. First, where do you see the lease spreads settling in 2016? It looks like you ended 2015 with about a 14% average. And then Bobby, I think you said that the average duration of leases signed in 2015 was 6.2 years. And jus
componenttext: I have 2 quick leasing questions. First, where do you see the lease spreads settling in 2016? It looks like you ended 2015 with about a 14% average. And then Bobby, I think you said that the average duration of leases signed in 2015 was 6.2 years. And just out of curiosity, is that shorter than it's historically been? And can you give us a little color on that?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. In terms of the first question, our target is to maintain mid-teens spreads. The nature of the statistics, sometimes it will bump up, sometimes it will bump down, but our goal is for mid-teens spreads. And we believe, based on current market conditi
componenttext: Sure. In terms of the first question, our target is to maintain mid-teens spreads. The nature of the statistics, sometimes it will bump up, sometimes it will bump down, but our goal is for mid-teens spreads. And we believe, based on current market conditions, we can achieve that. In terms of the average lease term, it's actually increasing. As the portfolio's improved in quality over the last 3 years, we've seen that number increase to longer durations.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ki Bin Kim.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ki Bin Kim.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Going back to your comments on retailer bankruptcies that might be a little bit more this year than last year, how much of that is actually configured into your guidance? I see that your bad debt expense is kept flat. From a assumption standpoint, this di
componenttext: Going back to your comments on retailer bankruptcies that might be a little bit more this year than last year, how much of that is actually configured into your guidance? I see that your bad debt expense is kept flat. From a assumption standpoint, this differs last year, while your lease [indiscernible] income ticked up $5 million. So just curious if you've taken some kind of reserve for those expectations.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we -- it's resulted in more conservative revenue assumptions on the lease-up. There has been some red concession conversation that has also been factored into the 2016 guidance. The increase in lease termination revenues just because we currently ar
componenttext: Well, we -- it's resulted in more conservative revenue assumptions on the lease-up. There has been some red concession conversation that has also been factored into the 2016 guidance. The increase in lease termination revenues just because we currently are in discussion with a number of tenants. So that's a specific number. Generally, we assume $10 million to $11 million going in new year as our assumption based on history. And so we still have that general assumption, but we have a few specific tenants that we have been negotiating with, which is also a by-product of what Bobby said is typically when you have times when you have store closures, it's not always bankruptcies, and it can then lead to more lease termination revenue.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a follow-up. I mean, we are a couple of months more into it than your last conference call. Anything incremental that you've discovered more on your retailers?
componenttext: Okay. And just a follow-up. I mean, we are a couple of months more into it than your last conference call. Anything incremental that you've discovered more on your retailers?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say none really. We haven't noticed a significant difference in discussions with tenants. The tenants that we are in discussion is pretty much the same group as we talked about in the third quarter. So I think the holiday season didn't provide any
componenttext: I would say none really. We haven't noticed a significant difference in discussions with tenants. The tenants that we are in discussion is pretty much the same group as we talked about in the third quarter. So I think the holiday season didn't provide any surprises negatively or positively.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And next, we have Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: And next, we have Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a few questions. First, on the same-store NOI guidance, I know in the second quarter call last year, you guys talked about trying to maintain sort of a 6% number. Sort of like what you've delivered in '15 over the next few years. This year, the NOI g
componenttext: Just a few questions. First, on the same-store NOI guidance, I know in the second quarter call last year, you guys talked about trying to maintain sort of a 6% number. Sort of like what you've delivered in '15 over the next few years. This year, the NOI guidance is below that, but yet the bottom line FFO number exceeds what the Street was expecting. So can you just help us walk through if we should expect same-store NOI to get back to that 6% number or maybe there's some non-same-store items that are really driving the FFO beat relative to consensus?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that 2 -- first, I'll take the NOI question, Alex. There's a comment made in July of '15 that, it's a caveat that it wasn't guidance, but that internally we were hoping to see same-center NOI growth of 6% over the next couple of years. And you very w
componenttext: Yes, that 2 -- first, I'll take the NOI question, Alex. There's a comment made in July of '15 that, it's a caveat that it wasn't guidance, but that internally we were hoping to see same-center NOI growth of 6% over the next couple of years. And you very well -- when you combine '15 and '16, it could average to close to 6%. And I will say that, subsequent to July, leasing environment has been viewed more cautiously as before. In fact, looking at some comments made by my colleague to my right here, Bob Perlmutter, [indiscernible] was looking toward end of the year, we're anticipating that bankruptcies are likely to be comparable or higher than in previous years. And he went on in some length. And in fact, to the extent that internally he earned himself, as a result of that call, the nickname of "dark cloud". So I would say that in the second half of the year, we became more cautious as it related in leasing environment, and it certainly affected the 6% growth rate that had been discussed earlier in the year. In terms of the FFO number, a lot of components in there, Alex. Obviously, the joint ventures, which happened late in the year, all financing activity which came in at extremely attractive rates. All those things affected the FFO number as well as the buybacks and the accretion from those. We did have a lot of cash on the balance sheet, which is diluted. So there are many factors that went into the ultimate FFO number.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the second question is, on the development schedule, one, it looks like a few projects got pushed back a year, and maybe it's just -- as you get more to planning, stuff trues up, but also the spend on Philly increased as well as the time li
componenttext: Okay. And then the second question is, on the development schedule, one, it looks like a few projects got pushed back a year, and maybe it's just -- as you get more to planning, stuff trues up, but also the spend on Philly increased as well as the time line length. And so if you can just provide some perspective on that.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll take Philly, and then I'll let Bob talk about the timing. On Philly, in the shadow report, we've been netting out the city assistance. There's roughly $90 million of Citi assistance which has been, to a large degree, solidified. And so we are n
componenttext: Sure. I'll take Philly, and then I'll let Bob talk about the timing. On Philly, in the shadow report, we've been netting out the city assistance. There's roughly $90 million of Citi assistance which has been, to a large degree, solidified. And so we are now showing the gross number for the project and not netting it by the city assistance. Most of that city assistance will come in the form of a TIF. And under GAAP, TIF income is recognized as income, not reduction of cost. So that's right. That's gross [indiscernible] as a result of the change of the scope of the project.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Alex. In terms of timing, I don't think there's anything really significant other than working through the predevelopment process. Both of these projects are complicated projects. They're mixed-use projects, and it's taken some time to get it through
componenttext: Yes, Alex. In terms of timing, I don't think there's anything really significant other than working through the predevelopment process. Both of these projects are complicated projects. They're mixed-use projects, and it's taken some time to get it through the predevelopment process, get the pre-leasing commitments that we needed and ultimately move into the under construction pipeline.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just, finally, on Philly then. Thomas, if the city assistance is now in the gross number, the yield -- it's the yield that we think about the project returning that on the net basis, so that's inclusive of the gross of the city's contribution.
componenttext: And then just, finally, on Philly then. Thomas, if the city assistance is now in the gross number, the yield -- it's the yield that we think about the project returning that on the net basis, so that's inclusive of the gross of the city's contribution.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a function of the gross cost and the income from the TIF is included and calculate in that 8% return.
componenttext: It's a function of the gross cost and the income from the TIF is included and calculate in that 8% return.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: It really is just a function of just following GAAP in that. We weren't sure in the very beginning exactly what the format would be of the various assistance vehicles that we were able to attain, but the one -- and we exceeded our expectations on that sid
componenttext: It really is just a function of just following GAAP in that. We weren't sure in the very beginning exactly what the format would be of the various assistance vehicles that we were able to attain, but the one -- and we exceeded our expectations on that side of things. So we are ready to go, and it's really just now as we move it into the in-process pipeline, taking a look at how the GAAP numbers would require us to treat it.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Todd Thomas with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Todd Thomas with KeyBanc.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate the comments around e-com and brick-and-mortar. Just given all of those comments around buy online, pick up in store and the impact of return to store sales, how are conversations changing with retailers when you negotiate leases? And how are y
componenttext: Appreciate the comments around e-com and brick-and-mortar. Just given all of those comments around buy online, pick up in store and the impact of return to store sales, how are conversations changing with retailers when you negotiate leases? And how are you setting rent will all of those factors in mind?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Bob Perlmutter. I think -- your initial reaction is, "Well, we want to capture the sales per percentage rent." But that's not really the way we're looking at it. What we're really trying to do is understand the amounts and the impacts of all of th
componenttext: This is Bob Perlmutter. I think -- your initial reaction is, "Well, we want to capture the sales per percentage rent." But that's not really the way we're looking at it. What we're really trying to do is understand the amounts and the impacts of all of the different e-commerce strategies on the brick-and-mortar, not with the goal of gaining more percentage rent, but with the goal in terms of understanding how important these locations are with the retailers. So we're learning. We're teaming up with certain outside professionals. We're using rights we have under a lease, and it's really to understand how the physical store influences the e-commerce. And it's more than just what are their reported sales.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Also just to add to that, look, we think of ourselves as an omni-channel landlord, an omni-channel owner. And in that context, we see our duty and our opportunity to our retailers to be not only to provide them with the physical space in the mall, but to
componenttext: Also just to add to that, look, we think of ourselves as an omni-channel landlord, an omni-channel owner. And in that context, we see our duty and our opportunity to our retailers to be not only to provide them with the physical space in the mall, but to also support other activities that they have, like buy online deliver from store. Things of that nature. So it's an evolving business, but the one thing that is clear to us, and this kind of goes back as a follow-on to some of the same-center conversations, I'd say that the most important factor that drives your same-center NOI growth is the leasing demand and the rents that you can achieve. Our team is -- and we're not unusual, but our team is extremely well aware of what these locations are worth to retailers, and there's no science that "They should pay x percent of sales, per se." We just factor everything in, and the mark-to-market that we've been able to put up over the past many years has been with double-digit leasing spreads, and we see the opportunity to continue those kind of spreads as being very clearly in front of us. And the evolution of brick-and-mortar retailers into more omni-channel retailers makes physical stores more valuable to them. They're valuable not only from the viewpoint of what they sell from the store, but they're also valuable as a service to people -- to their customers, for customers to buy online and then bring it back to the store and exchange it for something else. So they think of all of their activities, and as Bobby was saying, it's really -- it's not so important the exact sales number. It's really more having a knowledge of what's important to that particular retailer, and then that helps you to drive the rents. And if you have must have real estate, which is our goal here, then you're able to put up very good numbers.

componenttext: Look we're trying -- people love to have a polls on where we see the near term for the business. Look, I hope that Bobby's caution here is not reflected in increased bankruptcies. I hope that we have fewer, but we're really just trying to give you our all-in view of where we see things, but I would want to reiterate that in putting out the results that we have just attained in 2015, and as we see the opportunities into 2016, we see the demand for our properties to be very strong. So maybe we're being a little too cautious. Time will tell. But we're telling you what's in our assumption, and assumptions are exactly that. And time will tell. And it's our goal, obviously, to put up the best possible results, but there are certain things, like third-party retailer failures, that you don't necessarily control, right? I know we've talked about a lot, but I kind of would prefer it not become a headline. I know we're a bit of an outlier in our caution, and I hope that we're wrong.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of answering the last question, clearly, over the last 3 years, we've tried to manage our portfolio and reduce our exposure to retailers that we felt were weaker. That happens more in the existing portfolio than in terms of new developments, whic
componenttext: In terms of answering the last question, clearly, over the last 3 years, we've tried to manage our portfolio and reduce our exposure to retailers that we felt were weaker. That happens more in the existing portfolio than in terms of new developments, which we obviously target the strongest retailers in the market for. In terms of where it impacts us, our position on many of the bankruptcies has been that, as part of a restructuring, you're investing in the retailers' business, and we only want to invest in the retailers that we think have a good long-term viability. And because of that, we have probably taken a little bit more stringent stance on not restructuring with certain retailers that have gone through bankruptcy. The net impact for us is a short-term negative in terms of potential loss of occupancy, but we think a long-term positive in terms of being able to replace the stores with stronger retailers at higher rents.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just on Country Club Plaza, can you talk about the importance of bringing in Taubman as a financial partner, what they bring to the table and why do they have the leasing responsibility?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're doing everything jointly. So from a merchandising viewpoint, Bobby and a couple of his key lieutenants and the person that runs leasing at Taubman, they've been collaborating and putting together a merchandising plan. And it's really going to
componenttext: Well, we're doing everything jointly. So from a merchandising viewpoint, Bobby and a couple of his key lieutenants and the person that runs leasing at Taubman, they've been collaborating and putting together a merchandising plan. And it's really going to be, I think, relationship-driven. But as we sit down and we identify which tenants we think that we want to either move out or to move in, whichever team has the better relationship with that tenant will take the lead. But you should think of it as joint, right, on all major decisions and a whole bunch of operating decisions. We did have to decide who is going to be the manager, and Taubman wanted to do the day-to-day management, and we were fine with that. Our focus with them is going to be more thinking about the marketing, merchandising and potential expansion opportunities that are available at the property. So why we do it together? We just both thought that it was a great opportunity, and we knew it was going to be a competitive situation in terms of bidding, and there were many bidders. We felt that the opportunity to be successful in buying it would be maximized if we join together to buy it. And so far, I think that we both feel very good about this investment opportunity. And it may have been that doing it together is what resulted in the best thinking in terms of coming up with the confidence to pay the price that was required here. So we feel very good about the thesis, and it's playing out, I believe, well. And we think that the Plaza has terrific upside. And I think, time will tell, but I think you're going to see some very significant opportunities for us to generate value there.

componenttext: One is in Denver. So Sears has already shrunk, and Primark has -- will be opening in the summer. Those were deals that were in process when we first started conversations with Sears, but those will happen this year again. And then the others, we're at different points of thinking through the opportunities. These were long-term investments that we made here, and we think that there's long term that -- from the protection of the overall value of the properties, owning key pieces of land is tremendously important. But also, we think that there are fundamental opportunities to be generated from each of them. Some will be bigger. Some will be smaller. And as we identify the opportunities, we'll talk about them. But we're not feeling any rush to say, "Okay, all 10 of them have been redeveloped or repositioned." We like the optionality that we have of being involved here. We're working together with [indiscernible] to come up with the best plans that we can come up with. And as we come up with those plants, then we'll go ahead and move forward towards implementing them.

componenttextpreview: Probably, the best measure that we can give you is the one that I stated you earlier that quoted the 15 leases versus the 14 [indiscernible] leases. I think it was 5.4% increase. The setting of market rents is not -- is more of an art than a science. Ther
componenttext: Probably, the best measure that we can give you is the one that I stated you earlier that quoted the 15 leases versus the 14 [indiscernible] leases. I think it was 5.4% increase. The setting of market rents is not -- is more of an art than a science. There's many, many factors that go into it, whether it's a new lease or renewal, what's the use, how the big the space, how much frontage, what are the options that the tenant has in the market. So it's not an exact science. And as we've talked a lot about in the past, we find that the dominant assets in the densely populated trade areas where the retailers have limited options always drive the highest rents.

componenttext: Welcome to The Macerich Company Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I'd like to remind everyone that this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Jean Wood, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, everyone, for joining us today on our fourth quarter 2015 earnings call. During the course of this call, management may make certain statements that may be deemed forward-looking within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities L
componenttext:
Thank you, everyone, for joining us today on our fourth quarter 2015 earnings call. During the course of this call, management may make certain statements that may be deemed forward-looking within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. We refer you to today's press release and our SEC filings for a detailed discussion of forward-looking statements. 
Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the earnings release and the supplemental filed on Form 8-K with the SEC. These are posted in the Investors section of the company's website at www.macerich.com. 
Joining us today are Art Coppola, CEO and Chairman; Tom O'Hern, Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Robert Perlmutter, Executive Vice President, Leasing; John Perry, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. 
With that, I would like to turn the call over to Tom.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jean. Consistent with past practice, we'll be limiting the call to 1 hour. If we run out of time and you still have questions, please do not hesitate to call me or John Perry or Jean. The fourth quarter reflected continued operational excelle
componenttext:
Thank you, Jean. Consistent with past practice, we'll be limiting the call to 1 hour. If we run out of time and you still have questions, please do not hesitate to call me or John Perry or Jean. 
The fourth quarter reflected continued operational excellence, as evidenced by the strength of our key operating metrics. We saw the successful completions of our joint venture strategy, the completion of a number of highly attractive financings, the reinvestment of capital into our best assets through redevelopment and share buybacks. We'll talk about these in greater detail later in the call. 
We continue to see very significant benefit from our efforts in 2012 through 2015 to sell noncore, slower-growing assets and redeploying that capital into higher-quality, more productive assets. 
Looking at the leasing activity. We had good volume in the fourth quarter. We signed leases under 10,000 square feet. We had 313,000 square feet signed. Positive re-leasing spread on a trailing 12-month basis of 14.2%. 
Looking at mall occupancy. It came in at 96.1%, up 30 basis points from 12/31 of '14, to about 70 basis points from our occupancy level at the end of the third quarter. Average mall store base rents also increased to $54.32, up from $51.15 a year ago. 
FFO for the quarter came in at $1.12. That compared to $0.99 for the quarter ended December 31, 2014. Same-center NOI increased by 6.4% in the quarter. And year-to-date NOI -- same-center NOI growth was a sector-leading 6.5%. This increase was driven by increased occupancy, double-digit re-leasing spreads, annual rent increases and aggressive operating cost management. 
Looking at the gross margin at the centers. It improved to 71% for the quarter, up from 68.6% in the fourth quarter of last year. Looking at the year-to-date, margin had improved by 250 basis points to 69.3% compared to 66.8% for the full year 2014. 
Bad debt expense for the quarter was up slightly at $1 million, comparing to $800,000 in the fourth quarter last year. The average interest rate at 3.6% was slightly higher than the 3.48% average rate at the end of 2014. 
The balance sheet continues to be in great shape. At quarter-end, looking at the key balance sheet metrics, debt-to-market cap was 34%. Interest coverage ratio was a very strong 4.0x. Debt to EBITDA on a forward basis, 7.2x. The average debt maturity, and this is after the Arrowhead financing and the closing of the joint venture, is at 6 years, up significantly from a few years ago. We did a total of about $3 billion in financing in 2015. And within the past quarter, we did $1.8 billion. It included Arrowhead, 12-year loan, $400 million at 4.05%; Los Cerritos, another 12-year loan at 4%; Washington Square, $550 million loan, 3.65%, 7 years; South Plains, Twenty Ninth Street, also refinanced. So that was $1.825 billion in financings, average tenure of 10.1 years and average interest rate of 3.94%. 
In mid-November, we set about to execute on our $1.2 billion of approved share buyback. We engaged an investment bank to do a $400 million accelerated stock repurchase program. At the beginning of that program, we received and retired 4.1 million shares, when the plan started, which was November 13, and the balance of the shares were to be delivered based on the average daily volume adjusted price of MAC during the buying period, less the negotiated discount. 
On January 20, 2016, the ASR program was completed. Effectively, MAC bought back $400 million worth of shares at $78.26. We received another 971,000 shares at that time. So this program, the first ASR under the $1.2 billion program, retired, in total, 5.1 million shares. 
Also, since the last call, we had 2 special dividends that resulted from the joint venture transactions. They were each -- of $2. One was paid in December and one in January. 
In our press release this morning, we provide 2016 FFO per share guidance. The range was $4.05 to $4.15. The guidance assumptions included same-center NOI growth of 4.5% to 5%, which is very significant given that 2015 is a tough comparison year, having come in at 6.5%. The acquisition and guidance includes a $330 million of our share of Country Club Plaza, which has been previously announced. It also reflects roughly $1 billion of dispositions, which relates to the joint venture interests that we closed in January with Heitman and GIC. 
The other assumptions are included in the 8-K supplement filed last night. Our NOI guidance for 2016 is consistent with the guidance we gave in early 2015 after adjusting for the impact of the joint ventures. 
At this point, I'd like to turn it over to Bobby to discuss the leasing environment.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. The leasing activity during the fourth quarter remained strong, reflecting the high-quality nature of the company's shopping centers. Occupancy increased to 96.1%, which represented a 30 basis point year-over-year increase. Permanent occupanc
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. The leasing activity during the fourth quarter remained strong, reflecting the high-quality nature of the company's shopping centers. Occupancy increased to 96.1%, which represented a 30 basis point year-over-year increase. Permanent occupancy ended the year at 90.5%. Temporary occupancy increased to 5.6%, which reflects the bankruptcies incurred at the end of 2014 and the beginning of 2015. During 2015, a total of 250,000 square feet was converted from temporary to permanent occupancy. 
Leasing spreads were 14.2%, again indicating strong demand for space in the portfolio. Leasing spreads were strongest in the East and West Coast centers. Average rent for leases signed in 2015 was $57.41 per square foot. This represented a 5.4% increase over the prior year. 
During the year, we signed leases for approximately 4 million square feet, which was a 2.4% increase over 2014. The average lease term for leases signed in 2015 was 6.2 years. 
Portfolio sales increased by 8.2% year-over-year to $635 per square foot. Comparable center sales increased by 7.6% year-over-year. Sales increases were highest in the West Coast and Arizona centers. And during 2015, sales were positively impacted by: one, high-volume tenants; two, strong categories such as home furnishing, jewelry, cosmetics and athletic footwear; three, organic growth from merchants with strong brands; and four, store closures of underproductive tenants. 
Tourism. While our portfolio only has moderate exposure to international tourists and luxury business, we have seen certain centers impacted by tourism and the stronger U.S. dollar. Most notable in our portfolio is Fashion Outlets of Niagara Falls, whose sales have been impacted by the steep decline in the Canadian dollar. 
Holiday sales. Most retailers are indicating holiday sales were in line with expectations. Black Friday sales have been distributed over most of the week, starting with pre-Thanksgiving sales. Retailers are also reporting the last few days before Christmas as well as the post-Christmas activity were stronger than expected. Many retailers were promotional throughout the entire season. We believe this is likely to increase the strain on those stores under financial pressure. In general, it appears that specialty stores fared better than department stores during the holiday season. 
2014 and 2015 bankruptcies. As we discussed during the third quarter earnings call, we expect bankruptcies and rent relief requests in 2016 to be at similar or higher levels than in 2015. This is reflected in our 2016 forecast. We believe many of these retailers are likely to restructure and reduce the number of locations within their fleet as opposed to liquidate the entire chain. This is likely to impact lower-productivity centers to a greater degree. 
During 2014 and 2015, there were 11 major store closings or bankruptcies that impacted 134 stores or 413,000 square feet within our portfolio. The average rent for these stores was $54 per square foot. They generated sales of $241 per square foot and had an occupancy cost of 22.6%. As of 12/31/15, 66% of the space has been re-leased, resulting in a significant upgrade to the merchandise mix, improved sales productivity and a rent spread in the high single digits. 
E-commerce. We are continuing to learn how retailers use their brick-and-mortar stores as a key component to support growth in their e-commerce sales. A number of important trends are emerging. One, the brick-and-mortar stores are integral to the e-commerce efforts. Two, BOPUS, bought online, pick up in stores, is becoming increasingly important to retailers. Three, online sales have a high percentage of returns, especially on apparel. Four, physical store sales are reduced by online returns, which reduces reported sales for brick-and-mortar locations. Five, the customers enter the mall equipped with more information from the web than ever before. Six, pure e-tailers are migrating into brick-and-mortar stores, generating new leasing opportunities. And seven, physical store presence improves online sales. 
These trends are supported by recent customer research conducted at a cross-section of Macerich centers. The research indicated that lower average expenditures and shorter-trip durations were more than offset by increased frequency of visits and higher conversion rates. We firmly believe that stores located in densely populated trade areas will benefit the most and increase in importance to the retailer. 
Big boxes. Throughout the portfolio, there is strong demand for big box users larger than 10,000 square feet. We've increased our exposure with retailers such as T.J. Maxx, HomeGoods, ULTA and Nordstrom Rack. These retailers have opened stores across the portfolio, including enclosed centers, open-air centers as well as lower-productivity centers. 
In addition, during the fourth quarter, we signed a lease with JCPenney at Inland Center to open in the former [indiscernible] building. JCPenney is on track for an opening in the fourth quarter of 2016. 
We continue to devote additional resources to activate the common areas of our centers. Efforts are orientated towards permanent kiosks and business development opportunities as well as incubation of online retailers into physical stores. Multiple goals for the common area include revenue enhancement, improved presentation and an elevated customer experience. 
Development. Leasing at the development projects remains on track. At Broadway Plaza, we have 87% of the expansion space under executed leases. We are very pleased with the merchandise mix and eager for the majority of the expansion to open during the second quarter of 2016. This will add to our existing anchors of Nordstrom, Macy's and Neiman Marcus. 
At Green Acres, anchored by Dick's -- at Green Acres Commons, anchored by Dick's Sporting Goods, we have 85% of the space under executed leases and are anticipating a third quarter opening in 2016. 
Finally, we have completed the public financing agreements and are moving forward with the development of Fashion Outlets of Philadelphia, in partnership with PREIT. This project is anticipated to be completed in late 2018 or early 2019, and will incorporate approximately 775,000 square feet of retail area. 
With that, I'd like to turn it over to Art.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bobby. Thanks, Tom. That's a lot to cover. So I'm going to cover just a few other items, and then we'll open it up to Q&A. As you can see, our operating results were terrific on every level, whether it be margin improvement, occupancy levels,
componenttext:
Thank you, Bobby. Thanks, Tom. That's a lot to cover. So I'm going to cover just a few other items, and then we'll open it up to Q&A. 
As you can see, our operating results were terrific on every level, whether it be margin improvement, occupancy levels, rents that we have in place in the portfolio, re-leasing spreads. All of these are factors that contributed to a very significant same-center NOI growth rate in 2015 and gives us optimism into the future as to our growth patterns over the next couple of years. It's hard to predict what's going to happen, obviously, in the retail broader environment. And there are many factors that could influence that up or down. But we recognize that if you think about all of the different levers that we can pull that can create shareholder value, that there probably is no lever more important than having the maximum possible same-center NOI growth pattern. Developments, redevelopments, these are also extremely value creation, but they obviously have capital that gets deployed as part of that process. It is a permanent lever that we will be pulling in the redevelopment arena or the new development arena. And we've got a very strong track record of positive results from those activities. And we anticipate that the projects that are under way right now will continue to drive value for us going forward. 
Another lever that we didn't anticipate that we were going to be able to pull, that would -- that gave us the opportunity, we feel, to create value here, was the selective disposition of a noncore asset, Panorama Mall in November of this past year. And the agreement with Macerich and Taubman to purchase Country Club Plaza in Kansas City from Highwoods Properties. That closing is anticipated to close March 1. The gross price is $660 million with a 50% anticipated loan to value that we would anticipate will be put on the property. Most all of our equity will be funded through the disposition proceeds that we generated from Panorama. Country Club Plaza is an iconic 15-block, 1.3-million square-foot mixed-use retail and office property located in the heart of Kansas City. It is well known throughout the industry. And we believe that jointly with Taubman, we will be successful in taking that property up to an even higher level of performance than where it is right now. We're very pleased to have completed the joint ventures that we did. That was a very significant and large capital decision or capital recycling decision and to effectively have raised new capital in the private markets through joint ventures, that was used to fund either -- both the special dividend that we paid out as well as to fund the stock buyback program that we've announced. And we're pleased that just a couple of months after announcing the $1.2 billion authorization, that we've got over 1/3 -- we got about 1/3 of that has been accomplished and delivered to date. So we're very happy about that. 
The status on the new developments. I think we're in very good shape there. If you take a look at Philadelphia, the redevelopment of Broadway Plaza, the addition of the theater to Santa Monica Place, the expansion of Green Acres and the recycling of the Sears building ultimately at Kings Plaza and Fashion Outlets of San Francisco, we think we're in a very good position for those projects to deliver good shareholder value into the future. But again, I would reiterate that, obviously, on a risk-adjusted basis, we see the opportunity to generate strong same-center NOI growth as being one of the most attractive levers that we can pull in creating shareholder value. 
So with that, operator, I'd like to open it up for Q&A.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Craig Schmidt with Bank of America.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: In thinking about comping against the tougher same-store NOIs, how much more room do you have in terms of these aggressive operating cost management?
componenttext: In thinking about comping against the tougher same-store NOIs, how much more room do you have in terms of these aggressive operating cost management?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Craig, some of that will flow into 2016. We really set out to do that in the second quarter. So we'll probably have 1 1/2 quarters of that, which will positively benefit 2016. We really pretty aggressively manage those. We'll continue to do that, but I do
componenttext: Craig, some of that will flow into 2016. We really set out to do that in the second quarter. So we'll probably have 1 1/2 quarters of that, which will positively benefit 2016. We really pretty aggressively manage those. We'll continue to do that, but I don't think we'll see the same kind of cuts in 2016 as we had in 2015. So it's hard to duplicate. I think we can maintain what we did, but it's going to be hard to replicate the same amount.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then -- and when thinking about possibly selling some more of your noncore assets, how many more assets would you like to sell out of the portfolio?
componenttext: And then -- and when thinking about possibly selling some more of your noncore assets, how many more assets would you like to sell out of the portfolio?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We really don't have a number per se. It's really opportunistic at this point. We really have taken the portfolio, in terms of its composition, to where we wanted to get it, with well over 95% of our NOI being fortress-type of income. So anything that we
componenttext: We really don't have a number per se. It's really opportunistic at this point. We really have taken the portfolio, in terms of its composition, to where we wanted to get it, with well over 95% of our NOI being fortress-type of income. So anything that we do, going forward, the way that we think about it is that dispositions will be there as a source of capital for us over the next, say, 3 to 5 years, to fund opportunities, whether they be development, redevelopment or potentially even an acquisition of something. So there is no specific number, but we clearly do intend to periodically continue to prune the portfolio and to recycle the capital. Funding the purchase of a great center like Country Club Plaza with the disposition of a very mature kind of enclosed community center equity source of capital is really, from my viewpoint, a great trade for the company. And likewise, funding development and redevelopment capital going forward through selling off noncore assets is also, to me, a very sensible thing to do.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: I have 2 quick leasing questions. First, where do you see the lease spreads settling in 2016? It looks like you ended 2015 with about a 14% average. And then Bobby, I think you said that the average duration on leases signed in 2015 was 6.2 years. And just out of curiosity, is that shorter than it's historically been? And can you give us a little color on that?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. In terms of the first question, our target is to maintain mid-teens spreads. The nature of the statistics, sometimes it will bump up, sometimes it will bump down, but our goal is for midteen spreads. And we believe, based on current market condition
componenttext: Sure. In terms of the first question, our target is to maintain mid-teens spreads. The nature of the statistics, sometimes it will bump up, sometimes it will bump down, but our goal is for midteen spreads. And we believe, based on current market conditions, we can achieve that. In terms of the average lease term, it's actually increasing. As the portfolio's improved in quality over the last 3 years, we've seen that number increase to longer durations.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
