componenttextpreview: Arrow [ph] and PacSun are working through restructurings. PacSun appears to be making more progress. We have packages that have been worked out with both of them. In general, there's a few store closures, some rent relief and some assumptions. So the impa
componenttext: Arrow [ph] and PacSun are working through restructurings. PacSun appears to be making more progress. We have packages that have been worked out with both of them. In general, there's a few store closures, some rent relief and some assumptions. So the impact on the back half of the year is factored into the projection, it's not a material number either way.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I'm just curious on the WithMe partnership at Santa Monica and Century 21, I'm just curious, if you could comment on how that went? What the lineup looks like for the rest of the year there? And maybe if there has been any discussions with Centu
componenttext: Okay. And I'm just curious on the WithMe partnership at Santa Monica and Century 21, I'm just curious, if you could comment on how that went? What the lineup looks like for the rest of the year there? And maybe if there has been any discussions with Century 21 subsequent to their 6-week venture there?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: They were pleased with what they accomplished out of their exposure. And I think, in that case, it also -- I think they measured success as much about the extension of their brand awareness as they did the actual sales that they consummated. We'll be anno
componenttext: They were pleased with what they accomplished out of their exposure. And I think, in that case, it also -- I think they measured success as much about the extension of their brand awareness as they did the actual sales that they consummated. We'll be announcing another new retailer that will be taking that space in the near term. And that partnership is going well. It's focused on a number of locations. Going forward, the majority of those locations will be common area locations. Because we think that's probably the most efficient way and the most interesting way to go ahead and deploy with their technology.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll now go to Andrew Rosivach from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we'll now go to Andrew Rosivach from Goldman Sachs.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Caitlin Burrows. I just had another question on the Kings Plaza redevelopment. It looks like the expected yields went from 7% to 8% down to 4%, in part, is due to increased expected costs. So I was wondering what is driving that extra cost.
componenttext: This is Caitlin Burrows. I just had another question on the Kings Plaza redevelopment. It looks like the expected yields went from 7% to 8% down to 4%, in part, is due to increased expected costs. So I was wondering what is driving that extra cost.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really, I think, just the fact of demising it into multiple locations a few more than we had otherwise anticipated. It was a placeholder before, that's why we put it into the shadow pipeline. But it's evolving. These are the numbers that we see today
componenttext: It's really, I think, just the fact of demising it into multiple locations a few more than we had otherwise anticipated. It was a placeholder before, that's why we put it into the shadow pipeline. But it's evolving. These are the numbers that we see today. I think it is important to note that we believe we're being very conservative in the way that we are reporting this return to you. I'm aware of other owners of malls that when they bring in a replacement department store, sometimes they include what they think is going to be the uplift in market rents for the entire mall into the return they expect to get from that department store. And I'm not saying that in a critical way, I'm saying that because I'm just aware there are different ways of thinking about what your return is when you replace a department store. We're not doing in this situation. And we're looking at it, comparing it to the very substantial ramp that Sears would have been paying over the next couple of years. Now Sears, their lease expired anyway in a couple of years. So you could argue that the 8% return is really the more realistic return, but we wanted to -- look, we know that a lot of you are trying to do models based upon this information and that is as important as the return that we're reporting. And so we wanted to help you with the model. And let you know it's really 4% over what we're getting right now. As we think about it, we -- look, we do think about it long term. And we think about any investment in a replacement of the department store or any investment of that size in terms of IRRs over an expected holding period also. And the actual IRR on that particular investment, and this is just again going over the current rents that Sears is paying approaches 10%. So the company and the board felt very comfortable going forward that -- go ahead, Bob.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Caitlin, the only thing I would add, as we got into the redevelopment of the box, we clearly felt it was more than just taking the box and dividing it up for tenants. We felt there was an opportunity to really create a front door to the shopping center, w
componenttext: Caitlin, the only thing I would add, as we got into the redevelopment of the box, we clearly felt it was more than just taking the box and dividing it up for tenants. We felt there was an opportunity to really create a front door to the shopping center, which it's really lacking now, an opportunity to really open up the façade, an opportunity to get vertical transportation from the parking deck into the fourth floor tenant. So we definitely felt that it was a major redevelopment for the property and there's a lot of items in there that are more than just taking the box and carving it up and maximizing the revenues.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, yes. And then on just that idea of when you guys were talking about being conservative and thinking about it like this is the new rent you'll get kind of above and beyond what Sears was paying before. When you think about the other redevelopment pro
componenttext: Okay, yes. And then on just that idea of when you guys were talking about being conservative and thinking about it like this is the new rent you'll get kind of above and beyond what Sears was paying before. When you think about the other redevelopment projects you have, is that similar to how you calculate the return spend, again thinking about who's there now and what the incremental add will be as opposed to the total?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Looking at it, and stepping away from it, for example, when we thought about the return that we would be seeing at Walnut Creek, we looked at what was our opportunity cost. What would the income be, which was averaging around $15 million at the time.
componenttext: Yes. Looking at it, and stepping away from it, for example, when we thought about the return that we would be seeing at Walnut Creek, we looked at what was our opportunity cost. What would the income be, which was averaging around $15 million at the time. And so we've measured the return on investment over the income that was in place before we started tearing down buildings. And so after we got done tearing down buildings, we took that income down to around $8 million or $9 million. We didn't measure our incremental return from the reduced level. We measured it from what it used to be in the kind of do-nothing scenario.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll move on Paul Morgan with Canaccord.
componenttext: And we'll move on Paul Morgan with Canaccord.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciated the discussion about rent spreads and the top 2/3 and bottom 1/3, and I just wanted to kind of follow up on that. I mean, how much of kind of that discrepancy in sales productivity is something that you think you can kind of just monetize? W
componenttext: I appreciated the discussion about rent spreads and the top 2/3 and bottom 1/3, and I just wanted to kind of follow up on that. I mean, how much of kind of that discrepancy in sales productivity is something that you think you can kind of just monetize? We can just sort of take a kind of a mark-to-market approach versus -- I mean it feels like there would be some other factors like what specific malls, maybe the locations in the malls, it would seem like there's going to be certain locations that are just always going to be less productivity if it's near end cap with the weaker anchors, things like that. I mean how kind of -- how easy is it just to map that difference $313 to $1,000 a foot to kind of what you're upside is going to be?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, since this is what I've been doing for a living for over 40 years, and since it's been this way every day of those 40 years, and since it really hasn't been any change, I feel very comfortable with our ability to continue to recycle tenants, it's wh
componenttext: Well, since this is what I've been doing for a living for over 40 years, and since it's been this way every day of those 40 years, and since it really hasn't been any change, I feel very comfortable with our ability to continue to recycle tenants, it's what you do. It's the nature of the business. But remember, I think one of my peers indicated to you in a call a few quarters ago, I think he was observing that because top 10 tenants, when he went public 20-some years ago, there's only 2 or 3 of them are still in business. Well, does that mean that the business went bad? Or does that mean that we have 8 great new top 10 tenants? And frankly, the answer is, we got 8 really good new guys. And the 8 guys that went away, they went away because they had matured. And I feel -- look, it all comes back to supply and demand. And we can dissect this to the nth degree. But the way that we look at things is that we think about not what is, but what can be. So we don't think about a space where a tenant's doing $300 a foot and say that's a $300 space, we look at it and say potentially that's a $300 space because it's a crappy tenant. We had a tenant at Santa Monica Place on the second level that I think was doing $300 a foot, Bobby, a 10,000-foot tenant, an apparel tenant and we didn't say, "Oh, that's a $300 a foot location." And we replaced them with a really good new tenant who is doing probably 3x that, which -- that's what we do every day. And by the way, it's not just us, it's our peers do that also. Now, I will tell you that we're able to do that because we have -- we have properties that are must-have properties. If we had commodity type of properties or we were located in some really secondary or tertiary markets or we were dealing with a portfolio of significantly lower-quality properties, we wouldn't be in a position to have this conversation. But we are in high-demand locations with great real estate, somewhat similar to high street retail and the demand characteristics and returns and rent growth that those have enjoyed over the years. It's supply and demand. It all comes down to that.

componenttextpreview: So I mean, it sounds like you would attribute a lot of that difference in sales productivity to things that are specific to the retailer rather than like being on an end cap [ph] say, typically?

componenttextpreview: Absolutely. Right. Now look, there's several locations that are always going to be less productive, but that's all baked into the numbers. And when we looked at and we said the top 2/3 of our tenants in each category do over $1,000 a foot, then the bottom
componenttext: Absolutely. Right. Now look, there's several locations that are always going to be less productive, but that's all baked into the numbers. And when we looked at and we said the top 2/3 of our tenants in each category do over $1,000 a foot, then the bottom 1/3 by category do $313 a foot to average $726, that wasn't location-specific, it was just saying, "All right, if I've got 9 tenants in this category, what are the top 6 doing and what are the bottom 3 doing?" And it doesn't matter where they're located. So it is a function frankly of, are you selling the merchandise that people want to buy?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then just going back to the Kings redevelopment number. I definitely appreciate the kind of the clarity of that 4%, which we don't necessarily often see. I mean is the gap between your gross yield and your net yield, that meaningful there? Or is it just because of the complexity and urban nature of Kings and the fact that Sears was paying pretty material rent that the difference is so wide?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think as Bob mentioned, there's a fair amount of work that's being done within that box that is really common area in nature. Again, it's really mall-specific and not tenant-specific. So we're creating a new atrium entrance to Flatbush Boulevard,
componenttext: Well, I think as Bob mentioned, there's a fair amount of work that's being done within that box that is really common area in nature. Again, it's really mall-specific and not tenant-specific. So we're creating a new atrium entrance to Flatbush Boulevard, which really has nothing to do with redemising the space. But I will tell you that when it comes to anchor replacement, we don't expect that to be returns that are going to be the normal 8% to 10% types of return. And if we can achieve returns that we think are adequate, and we think about that, both cash-on-cash, we think about it in terms of a 10-year hold, or if we think about its impact on the mall and everything considered, we're going to be willing to, if we believe that we can dramatically improve the quality of the draw, we're very happy to take a mid-single-digit type of return on a replacement. Very happy to do it. And it's the right thing to do.

componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to The Macerich Company Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would like to remind you that this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Jean Wood, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining us today on our third quarter 2016 earnings call. During the course of this call, management may make certain statements that may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Safe Harbor of the Private
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining us today on our third quarter 2016 earnings call. During the course of this call, management may make certain statements that may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Safe Harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. We refer you to today's press release and our SEC filings for a detailed discussion of forward-looking statements. 
Reconciliation of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the earnings release and supplemental filed on Form 8-K with the SEC, which are posted in the Investor sections of the company's website at www.macerich.com.
Joining us today are Art Coppola, CEO and Chairman; Tom O'Hern, Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Robert Perlmutter, Senior Vice President and Chief Operating Officer; and John Perry, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations. 
We look forward to seeing many of you at our investor event on Monday, November 14, in Phoenix in conjunction with the Mayberry [ph] Conference. And with that, I will turn the call over to Tom.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jean. Consistent with past practice, we're going to be limiting this call to 1 hour. If we happen to run out of time and you still have questions, please don't hesitate to give me a call, or John or Jean. The third quarter reflected continued
componenttext:
Thank you, Jean. Consistent with past practice, we're going to be limiting this call to 1 hour. If we happen to run out of time and you still have questions, please don't hesitate to give me a call, or John or Jean. 
The third quarter reflected continued strong operating results as evidenced by the strength of most of our portfolio's key operating metrics. For the quarter, FFO was $1.04 per share, up from $1.01 in the third quarter of last year. 
Same-center NOI increased by 4.2% compared to the third quarter of '15, which was a very tough comp quarter that was up 7%. This was positively impacted by $7.8 million of lease termination revenues in the third quarter. So most cases, we were accelerating revenue we would have received in the fourth quarter and beyond into the third quarter. 
Year-to-date our same-center NOI growth is 6%. And as we discussed in our last earnings calls, most of the impact of the major tenet bankruptcies this year will be felt in the third and fourth quarter, which means lower same-center NOI growth in the third and fourth quarter than we saw in the first half of the year.
Our same-center estimate for NOI for the year, the range being tightened to 4.5 to 4.75. As we look forward into 2017, we're not giving full guidance for the year, but we are going to give some guidance on our expectation for same-center NOI growth. It will be down slightly from this year, and we expect the range of 3% to 4% same-center growth in 2017. Keep in mind that for the first half of 2016, we have the comparative benefit of the expense cuts that were initiated in the third quarter of '15. We will not have that comparative benefit as we compare 2017 to 2016. 
Our gross operating margin on a same-center basis for the quarter improved to 69.6%. That was up from 68.5% in the third quarter of '15. And if we compare it to the third quarter of '14, 2 years ago, it's a 399-basis-point improvement. 
Year-to-date, the same-center gross margin was 69.33%, up from 67.9% during the same period of last year. Bad debt expense was a modest 300,000 for the quarter, down compared to $800,000 in the third quarter of last year. 
As I mentioned previously, lease termination fees were $7.8 million for the quarter. That compared to $3.4 million in the third quarter of last year. Most of these termination fees came from Sears of Kings Plaza where we exercised our right to terminate their lease early. This had the effect of accelerating about $2.5 million of rent that would have been paid in the fourth quarter into the third. 
During the third quarter, the average interest rate was 3.48%, up slightly from a year ago when it was 3.3.%. 
The balance sheet continues to be in great shape. At quarter end, our balance sheet metrics were healthy with debt-to-market cap of 37%, an interest coverage ratio of over 3.5x; debt-to-EBDA on a forward basis of 7.2%; and the average debt maturity after the financing of the Financing of Fashion Fair, which happened on October 6, is now over 6.5 years. 
The financing market for high-quality regional malls remains good. A couple of examples. On October 6, we closed the $325 million loan on the previously unencumbered Fresno Fashion Fair. It was a CMBS loan, the first one we've done in a while. 10-year fixed-rate of net interest rate of 3.59%. The proceeds from that financing were used to pay down our line of credit, with subsequent to that pay down is approximately 100 -- excuse me, $750 million outstanding. 
Also on August 5, we closed on a $225 million loan on The Village at Corte Madera. That was a life insurance company loan. The term was 12 years and has a fixed interest rate of 3.5%. 
I'm sure you saw in this morning's press release that we tightened our previous estimate of diluted FFO per share, and we narrowed the range to 4 05 to 4 10. That was down from 4 05 to 4 15. The revised FFO guidance comes primarily from reducing the midpoint of the range through the year on same-center NOI to 4.5% to 4.75%. That is down from an original guidance range of 4.5 to 5. 
The dilution from the sale of capital of the mall, which was not included in the initial guidance, is offset by the gain on extinguishment of debt on Flagstaff, which also is not in the original guidance. 
And now, I'd like to turn it over to Bob to discuss the tenant environment.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Recent activity during the third quarter was consistent with the first half of the year, producing strong releasing spreads and stable occupancies. Trailing 12-month leasing spreads were 16.1%. This is unchanged from the second quarter. Lea
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Recent activity during the third quarter was consistent with the first half of the year, producing strong releasing spreads and stable occupancies. 
Trailing 12-month leasing spreads were 16.1%. This is unchanged from the second quarter. Leasing spreads were relatively consistent through all the regions. 
Average rent for leases signed during the trailing 12-month period was $56.52. 
During the third quarter, a total of 803,000 square feet of leases were signed, down slightly from the previous quarter. The average term for leases signed in the third quarter increased to 7 years. 
Occupancy at the end of the third quarter was 95.3%. This represents a 30-basis-point increase on a quarter-over-quarter basis. Portfolio sales were $626 per square foot. And on a same-center basis, sales were up 1.3% year-over-year. 
I'm going to talk a minute about development. The third quarter represented an important milestone for the company as the developments of Broadway Plaza and Green Acres Commons celebrated their official grand openings. These 2 projects are illustrative of the company's strong development skills, taking unique retail locations and extending their market dominance through densification. Combined, these 2 developments represented an investment of $263 million and will produce a blended stabilized return over 9%. 
Over 10 years in the making, the expansion of Broadway Plaza began in 2012 when Neiman Marcus joined the existing anchors Nordstrom and Macy's at the center. We are extremely pleased with the merchandise mixed created at Broadway Plaza, and more importantly, the initial sales results from the tenants. The new space is 94% leased, and we anticipate all the retailers will be opened by this holiday season. 
Green Acres Commons celebrated its grand opening on October sixth. These two-level power center, anchored by Dick's Sporting Goods, is a strong addition to the Green Acres retail campus and provides a home for many big box retailers looking to tap this attractive New York market. 
There were also a number of important anchor openings in the portfolio. This served to further increase the drop from these established retail centers. 
At Fashion Outlets at Chicago, Nordstrom Rack opened its store on September 30. The center is now only 1 of 2 outlet venues in the U.S. that feature Nordstrom Rack, Saks OFF 5TH, Neimans Last Call, Bloomingdale's outlet and Barney's as its anchors. 
Dick's Sporting Goods opened a new store at The Oaks on October 11. In addition, 3 restaurants were added adjacent to Dick's. And finally, JCPenney had a very strong grand opening at Inland Center on October 21. The reception from the community was outstanding. 
I'm going to take a minute to talk about 10 of bankruptcies. There has been significant tension surrounding the health of certain specialty stores tenants. You recall, we entered 2016 cautious in our expectations regarding tenant bankruptcy. During the third quarter, the 3 most prominent bankruptcies of 2016 were resolved, albeit in very different fashions. First, the bankruptcy of Sports Authority resulted in the liquidation of the entire chain. Almost all the stores were closed except for a small number of leases purchased by other retailers. Second, PacSun completed their restructuring with the major creditor maintaining control of the company. PacSun emerged from bankruptcy in September with a restructured balance sheet and most of its store fleet intact.  Finally, Aeropostale will emerge under the control of a consortium of buyers. It is anticipated that up to 500 stores will be retained. 
Most of the economic impact from these bankruptcies will be felt during the fourth quarter of 2016 and into 2017. As Art has discussed in the past, throughout the portfolio, our focus is to reduce the exposure to weaker, lower productivity tenants well before their enter the restructuring process. For example, in 2012, Aeropostale had 45 stores in our portfolio. When they entered bankruptcy, this number had been reduced to 27. This was achieved through the disposition of lower productivity centers replace the lease expiration with more productive tenants and early termination when the tenants still have the financial resources to pay termination fees. We expect our exposure with Aeropostale at the end of 2016 to be 19 store locations or approximately 78,000 square-feet. 
Looking forward to our leasing focus in the coming year will be the repurpose underproductive anchor department stores and replace the vacancy caused by recent tenant bankruptcies and early termination agreements. We believe opportunity exist in the anchor buildings by tapping demand from the big-box and large formats at specialty retailers. As discussed on the last earnings call, the opportunity to retenant the Sears box at Kings Plaza with retailers that include Primark and Zara represents a unique opportunity to move the center to the next level in terms of traffic, sales productivity and merchandise mix. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Art.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob, and thank you, Tom. Welcome to our call. As you can see from our numbers and our announcements, we had a very strong quarter. Our leasing spreads remained extremely strong, consistent with our belief that we have embedded growth within o
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob, and thank you, Tom. Welcome to our call. 
As you can see from our numbers and our announcements, we had a very strong quarter. Our leasing spreads remained extremely strong, consistent with our belief that we have embedded growth within our portfolio. We culminated an 18-month period of improving operating margins and achieved our goal of improving our operating margins by 400 basis points. And as Bob pointed out, during the quarter, we successfully completed on-time, on-budget and at the returns that were expected, the Green Acres expansion and the Broadway Plaza expansion. 
The Broadway Plaza expansion is an important one to contemplate. Private Plaza recently celebrated its 75th year in business, 75 years. We bought Broadway Plaza about 31 years ago, and at the time, it had an NOI of $3 million. Upon stabilization, we anticipate that NOI to be roughly $40 million. So this is testimony that great real estate in the hands of great management with a well-capitalized balance sheet can succeed in spite of any challenges to the retail environment and any changes to the retail environment. 
Our future we see to be very strong and bright. I am pleased, however, in the context of concerns over the retail environment that at this point in time with the completion of the Green Acres and the Broadway Plaza expansion, we have modest exposure in terms of our capital spend to a possible weak retail environment going forward over the near term. We only Philadelphia and Kings Plaza in process, and both of those are proceeding as planned in terms of the merchandising and releasing. 
Having said all of that, we feel the pain of our investors and those of you on this call that follow our company and our industry. Back on August 1, only a little less than 3 months ago, Mace, which was trading at $91 a share in the RMC, was at $12.80. Today, we are roughly at $72 a share and the RMC is down to $11.05. Malls as a sector are obviously, down 500 to 600 basis points more than the other sectors that comprise the RMC. Its the fundamentals about the mall business that has caused us to underperform. I would say from the viewpoint of our management that we see our fundamentals to be at least as strong today as we were 3 months ago, 6 months ago and 9 months ago. But it is hard to ignore the difference in terms of the performance of the sector. 
If we're going to look at what event have happened during the last 3 months that potentially led to, and has led to, this underperformance, it's hard to ignore the August 11 announcement by Macy's that they were closing 100 department stores. Many of our investors have expressed concern over this. 
I want to share with you our view about those store closures. First of all, it is healthy for any retailer to prudently prune their portfolio and to weed out unproductive business units and to focus their attention on their more productive business units. That's what we do as a company. Closing stores is a prudent thing and a stronger Macy's makes for a stronger mall base. As I look at our exposure to Macy's and to these closures, it's our understanding that when those closures are announced, that we will have one store in our portfolio at that point in time that will be on the closure list and we see the closure of that store to be a positive, not a negative. It's most likely going to be a West L.A. store and it's a situation that is ready for redevelopment as we discussed in previous calls. 
As I think further about department stores and I think about the anxiety that people have about department stores, I also think about regarding what has happened over the past 10 or 12 years with department stores. And one of the seminal events that happened in the department store industry was in 2005 when Macy's bought May company, and that caused a significant consolidation within the department store business. The combination of that event and the general underperformance of department stores over the last 10 or 12 years have actually been arguably a positive for monitors. I know that seems strange for me to say that, but let me share with you the reason why. 
With the consolidation of Macy's and makeup going back to 11 years ago, many of the brands that really make up the excitement within a department store began to look at the balance of power that they had on their negotiations with department stores and decided that they wanted to add another channel of distribution to their omni-channel approach. I think albeit at 11 years ago, I doubt that word will be used that much. But many of the great brands have relied predominantly on the distribution to be wholesale distribution through the department stores. And over a period of time, those brands have decided to open up full-price retail stores, and in many cases, flagship stores. And they comprised many of the best names that we have in the mall today. Names like , Michael Kors, Allyn Fisher, Hugo Boss, All Saints, Louis Vuitton, Tori Burch, Ted Baker, Armani, Mac Cosmetics, Burberry, True Religion, the list goes on. And we see that, that trend continuing, which is a trend that, as I have mentioned in the past, is a trend that you see generally in place in the global portfolios of other owners of shopping centers around the world. 
So we see the store closures of Macy's to be a positive, not a negative. We see its impact on Macerich to be a positive, not a negative. And as I look at the overall health of the department store business, let's not loose sight of the fact that it was only 3 years ago that many folks that probably are on this call right now felt that JCPenney was doomed in terms of their future. And at that point in time, we were bit of an outlie where we said, “Look, the one name that we see out there that we think is going to be in existence as a retailer 5 or 10 years after 2013 is going to be JCPenney.” And there's been much written about their turnaround. I can tell you that JCPenney stores look better than ever, and we're very happy with the new Penney store that we just t opened in center. 
Again, I feel your pain. I understand it, and -- but the fundamentals that we have here remain very strong. 
With that, I'd like to open it up for questions.

componenttext: So Bobby, just following up on your releasing spreads, which have been pretty consistent in the last few quarters around that 14% to 16% level. I mean, I know that doesn't include the rent adjustment. But just looking at your average base rent, your AVR growth is pretty flat-ish over the last year. So realizing that those maybe 2 different pools, but just wondering why would that sort of strength and spread you're not seeing more flow through into AVR? Has that -- is that an impacted by the rap release at all? And with your comment that the biggest impact from the 3 bankruptcies should be in Q4 in 2017, how should we think about that trend in AVR over the next 2 [ph] quarters?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Christine, it has been flat over sort of -- if you look at the 2015 compared to the first 3 quarters of '16, it is somewhat 2 separate pools. So we have to be careful about that. But the -- where -- I think as a general rule, we continue to see strong gro
componenttext: Christine, it has been flat over sort of -- if you look at the 2015 compared to the first 3 quarters of '16, it is somewhat 2 separate pools. So we have to be careful about that. But the -- where -- I think as a general rule, we continue to see strong growth in the more dominant centers. We continue to see sort of moderate-to-weaker growth into lesser productivity centers. And in terms of the impact of the lease amendments, we did run those numbers and the impact is not really material in our numbers. And what you need to remember is within the pool of these restructurings, some of the stores are closed, which, obviously, don't affect the spread. Some of the stores are assumed, which don't affect the spreads. So if you to look at your lease amendments, it's only the ones, which you're modifying the lease, which tend to be some percentage of the total leases. It's been done down [ph] at 100%.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of the margin improvement, you're about a year and I think a significant portion of the expansion is pretty well big to points. So can you just talk a little bit more about the revenue side of where you're at today pushing some of those revenue e
componenttext: In terms of the margin improvement, you're about a year and I think a significant portion of the expansion is pretty well big to points. So can you just talk a little bit more about the revenue side of where you're at today pushing some of those revenue enhancements? And how much more runway is there? Are we talking about maybe another 100 basis points in margin expansion in that 3% to 4% 2017 to your expectation?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'm happy to take ownership of that. Look, we've got a lot of time to really calculate how much margin improvement we thought that we could obtain. We put a goal of 400 basis points over a 2-year period. We announced that about 18 months ago, and th
componenttext: Sure. I'm happy to take ownership of that. Look, we've got a lot of time to really calculate how much margin improvement we thought that we could obtain. We put a goal of 400 basis points over a 2-year period. We announced that about 18 months ago, and then we've achieved that in less than the 2 years. I don't think there is greater -- that there's significantly more room for margin improvement from -- on the expense side, but we remain diligent about expenses at all times. I do believe that there is continued improvement on the revenue side, but I'm not going to put a target out there that will be held accountable for other than a promise that we will report to you as time goes on, and my suspicion is that there's upside in that number.  That's certainly our goal and we have plants. We know how we're going to get there, and -- but we'll report that on as we go along.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And just as a follow up here. Just given some of the pressures we had on the high-end outlets space, does this impact in any of your thinking on a fashion outlet to San Francisco at this point? Or still too early?
componenttext: All right. And just as a follow up here. Just given some of the pressures we had on the high-end outlets space, does this impact in any of your thinking on a fashion outlet to San Francisco at this point? Or still too early?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it has not affected our thinking. But look, as I've mentioned, there are anxieties out there in general for coming from many different arenas. It's hard to ignore the headwinds that come from all kinds of different places, whether it be the strong dol
componenttext: No, it has not affected our thinking. But look, as I've mentioned, there are anxieties out there in general for coming from many different arenas. It's hard to ignore the headwinds that come from all kinds of different places, whether it be the strong dollar or the tourism spending reducing, whatever the anxieties are. And so as I mentioned in my comments, I think we are pleased to have a modest capital spent in place. We're in good shape at this point in time in terms of our marketing and leasing of the 2 projects that we're spending money on, things in Philadelphia. And we have the ability on anything else that we do in the future to time the shovel in the ground to signed leases.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Craig Schmidt with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Craig Schmidt with Bank of America.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nice to hear the good news you're only having one Macy's closed out of years. However, we're starting to look like the REIT in general will not have as many closings as other private malls, but what do you think might happen to some of those lower quality
componenttext: Nice to hear the good news you're only having one Macy's closed out of years. However, we're starting to look like the REIT in general will not have as many closings as other private malls, but what do you think might happen to some of those lower quality private malls as they loose the Macy's and their ability to remain viable?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The good news is I don't have to spend time thinking about that, and I don't have an answer for you right off the top of my head. We made a decision. The flip side of that is that look, it's not surprising that the public companies, which tend to own the
componenttext: The good news is I don't have to spend time thinking about that, and I don't have an answer for you right off the top of my head. We made a decision. The flip side of that is that look, it's not surprising that the public companies, which tend to own the better properties, have lesser exposure. It's not surprising that Macerich, which has been extremely diligent in pruning our portfolio, has even less exposures than you would expect. So we see -- look, we see it as healthy for Macy's. Here's the flip side though also. If Macy's had like ignored the idea of pruning their portfolio, I think the latter commentary should be why aren't they closing stores? So here they come out and decide to be prudent and smart in running their business, and all of a sudden. I understand it. And look, it came out of kind of left field for a lot of people. We kind of thought I thought that Macy's was okay. But was -- it's good for the business. And what's good for them is good for us. And whether in Macy's or any other anchor that we have in the portfolio that we own, we see it as opportunities generally. We see the opportunities to replace them with other users that draw traffic and then do the job of what an anchor is supposed to do. So from my viewpoint, I don't see that as a negative at all.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just has there been any forward progress in terms of Fashion Outlets in Philadelphia in some of the maybe bigger space getting taken up?
componenttext: Okay. And then just has there been any forward progress in terms of Fashion Outlets in Philadelphia in some of the maybe bigger space getting taken up?

componenttext: Yes. And announcements will be made as leases are signed and as we deem it appropriate in terms of the marketing of the property. But we just had an all-day session with our leasing team on that project yesterday, and we are in good shape at this point in time.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we haven't gotten back to that level of disclosure in the guidance. But at $19 million for 2016, that's extraordinarily high for us. I mean, we've been averaging 10% to 12%. That's always a trade-off when you take that termination. For example, you
componenttext: Well, we haven't gotten back to that level of disclosure in the guidance. But at $19 million for 2016, that's extraordinarily high for us. I mean, we've been averaging 10% to 12%. That's always a trade-off when you take that termination. For example, you made the decision the terminate Sears early because you're foregoing future minimum rent and charges. I mean, it is factored in to our thinking in general that we will have that lease term revenue that's as high as we got this year.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then looking at a couple of your top centers. So Queens Center sale the past couple of years have been about $1,100 a feet. This year, it looks like you're over $1,300. And then Washington Square where there were 1,100 a foot for the cos
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then looking at a couple of your top centers. So Queens Center sale the past couple of years have been about $1,100 a feet. This year, it looks like you're over $1,300. And then Washington Square where there were 1,100 a foot for the cost past couple of years. It's down to about $1,000. I was wondering if there's anything specifically going on in those 2 centers? Or just put a bit of color.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Bob Perlmutter. The Queens had a Apple store that annualized and was brought into the pool. So that impacted the sales per square foot. And Washington Square is a no-sales tax state, so we actually had the opposite in terms of some of the com
componenttext: Yes. This is Bob Perlmutter. The Queens had a Apple store that annualized and was brought into the pool. So that impacted the sales per square foot. And Washington Square is a no-sales tax state, so we actually had the opposite in terms of some of the commercial sales being transferred out of the retail store in [indiscernible] their venues.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next we have Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Next we have Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe, Tom, just some quick guidance questions and then I'll maybe Bobby. But first, in the guidance, some of the changes that we noted were the impact of asset sales from last year and earlier this. This year is now expected to be $80 million versus $75
componenttext: Maybe, Tom, just some quick guidance questions and then I'll maybe Bobby. But first, in the guidance, some of the changes that we noted were the impact of asset sales from last year and earlier this. This year is now expected to be $80 million versus $75 million. And then the debt gain impact also changed. It went from, I think, a negative sort of down 2 to positive plus 4.5. Can you just walk us through what happened from second quarter when you provided the guidance to now what changed in.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and you may have missed this, Alex. I think we already talked about this early in the call, but there's really two things. We sold capital, which happened in the second quarter. Obviously, we knew about that, but we're not about to meet your react an
componenttext: Yes, and you may have missed this, Alex. I think we already talked about this early in the call, but there's really two things. We sold capital, which happened in the second quarter. Obviously, we knew about that, but we're not about to meet your react and change guidance just for that one item because we're also in negotiations with the loan servicer on Flagstaff for that asset to go back. And we knew when it ultimately happened and titled was transferred. We recognize the gain in this 2 roughly offsetting. So it certainly didn't warrant us changing guidance down for capital and then turning around the next quarter moving it up for Flagstaff. So those 2 netted out.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. Then that's helpful. And then second is on the Street retail versus the malls. Here in New York, you obviously got Kings and Queens that would presumably compete with some of the street retail locations. And in Chicago, you have 500 North Mich
componenttext: Okay. Okay. Then that's helpful. And then second is on the Street retail versus the malls. Here in New York, you obviously got Kings and Queens that would presumably compete with some of the street retail locations. And in Chicago, you have 500 North Michigan that's on The Avenue as well as in line. Have you noticed a change in the way that retailers as you talk to them? As they're viewing their street retail presence versus the mall present? My point is do the retailers think of those in concert? Or do they think of each as different and The Street retail is a different leasing decision than the mall retail? Or within a certain metro or submarket, maybe we're together and it's just basically where they think they can get more traffic?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, it's Bob Perlmutter. I would say they really give a different -- I mean, a couple of distinctions. Kings and Queens really don't compete with The Street retail in Manhattan or New York. It's a more traditional mall mix, and their strength really com
componenttext: Alex, it's Bob Perlmutter. I would say they really give a different -- I mean, a couple of distinctions. Kings and Queens really don't compete with The Street retail in Manhattan or New York. It's a more traditional mall mix, and their strength really comes from the density of the population and the lack of alternatives for these retailers. Northbridge has a little bit of both. It has both sort of the traditional mall space as well as some street space. Generally, there's a pretty big distinction between what the retailers are trying to achieve on The Street on these flagship locations or inside the mall. So they tend to be different decision. And often, the real estate decision is controlled by different people within the retailer. So there's not really a situation where somebody says I'm going to -- The Street market is getting soft. I'm going to put more resources into the mall or vice versa.” They're really, in our mind, 2 independent decisions.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Morgan with Canaccord Genuity.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Morgan with Canaccord Genuity.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just trying to kind of triangulate various numbers. If I take where your guidance is now for this year, you did about 7 in the first half of the year and 4 this quarter. So that would put you, I guess, around 1 or so in the fourth quarter. And I know
componenttext: I'm just trying to kind of triangulate various numbers. If I take where your guidance is now for this year, you did about 7 in the first half of the year and 4 this quarter. So that would put you, I guess, around 1 or so in the fourth quarter. And I know that's some of that's to the lease term income, it sounds like. But if the back half is in kind of in the 2 to 3 range, it sounds like there's some kind of movement higher as you look into next year. I mean, is there anything kind of getting wrong? Or if there is some of the higher kind, what would that be due to?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you've got a number of things impact in the fourth quarter. We've accelerated some rents, Sears for example at Kings Plaza, and pushed that into the third quarter with normally would have been in the fourth, which is very sizeable. That was
componenttext: Well, I think you've got a number of things impact in the fourth quarter. We've accelerated some rents, Sears for example at Kings Plaza, and pushed that into the third quarter with normally would have been in the fourth, which is very sizeable. That was about $3 million in rent that got moved. And also, we're going to get through tough comps in the third and fourth quarter because we had the benefit of the expense cuts in the third and fourth quarter on a comp basis last year compared to this year and that will be recurring. So we see next year being fairly normal year. Wrestling through the final aspects of some of the bankruptcies from this year. But really, our same-center growth is driven by rent increases, which in general tend to be 2.5% to 3% in a given year. And generally, we look at these things in an occupancy neutral basis. And so I think fourth quarter was pretty unusual, and we don't think it's indicative of what next year will be like. And that's why we gave the guidance for next year.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess it's kind of safe to say that you don't see anybody in terms of watch list or kind of first quarter post-holiday bankruptcies?
componenttext: And I guess it's kind of safe to say that you don't see anybody in terms of watch list or kind of first quarter post-holiday bankruptcies?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: My last question on Macy's. It's good color there to. Macy's, in addition to kind of calling the bottom of the portfolio mentioned, that they might try to, like they did this year, to take out a couple of opportunistic closings at malls where there's bett
componenttext: My last question on Macy's. It's good color there to. Macy's, in addition to kind of calling the bottom of the portfolio mentioned, that they might try to, like they did this year, to take out a couple of opportunistic closings at malls where there's better use. I'm just wondering, in your portfolio, you now say that you've got a handful of malls where there's more than one Macy's with  stronger assets. I mean, is there something you would look to potentially recapture? Is your appetite for recapturing department store space changed at all now, given your current view of the leasing environment? Or is that something you'd be able to do?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I do think that -- thanks for the question. I do think that the one-store [indiscernible] that we're anticipating fits exactly into that category that there is a higher and better use and a user that's willing to pay them a compelling number to conv
componenttext: Well, I do think that -- thanks for the question. I do think that the one-store [indiscernible] that we're anticipating fits exactly into that category that there is a higher and better use and a user that's willing to pay them a compelling number to convert their store to a higher and better use. And the team that look at their overall representation and deem that to be appropriate for them, and we see it as potentially an opportunity for us. As we look at the rest of the stores that we have with Macy's, there are opportunities in certain locations to repurpose either some of their square footage, downsize them or maybe even completely replace them with a higher and better use. We're in conversations with them. This is going to be, I think, a longer conversation. I wouldn't predict that there will be any announcements from us anytime soon, but I would predict there will be announcements that would fit the category of converting some of their square footage in a location or all of their square footage in a location to a higher and better use that should happen sometime in the future. I also would anticipate that there will be announcements in the future where we and Macy's have worked together to just make the overall environment more profitable, and that could involve something that could be a monetization for them too.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Richard Hill with Morgan Stanley.

componenttext: This is one on Richard Hill's line. Just 2 quick ones for me. The first  is on kind of the financing market. I know you guys got in the CMT side. Just maybe give us a letter color on what you're seeing out there. And if so a potential financing you're trying to get done for [indiscernible]  for this year.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Islam is not unencumbered asset and it's available for financing. We haven't started that process yet, but it's certainly possible. We have been experienced at Fresno. We exposed that to CMBS market. The pricing, as you probably heard, at 3 59 for a
componenttext: Well, Islam is not unencumbered asset and it's available for financing. We haven't started that process yet, but it's certainly possible. We have been experienced at Fresno. We exposed that to CMBS market. The pricing, as you probably heard, at 3 59 for a tenured year. It was is fairly competitive. I would say it was -- we've been very competitive with the life of [indiscernible] that we done on that route. And I don't know how deep the market it. We were just really trying to finance that one particular asset, but I will tell you it was very competitive and it was probably 5 or 6 investment banks that stepped up with some pretty competitive quotes on that in a 10-year fixed rate deal.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The only thing I would add to that, Tom, is that look, regional malls remain one of the most attractive asset categories for lenders to place long term fixed-rate mortgages on.
componenttext: Yes. The only thing I would add to that, Tom, is that look, regional malls remain one of the most attractive asset categories for lenders to place long term fixed-rate mortgages on.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just going back to kind of the same-store NOI. I wondered if I back out the lease termination fees and pushed that to showing 2.1% growth for the quarter. One, is that right? And then when you look to 2017, is it possible where -- it's a t
componenttext: Great. And then just going back to kind of the same-store NOI. I wondered if I back out the lease termination fees and pushed that to showing 2.1% growth for the quarter. One, is that right? And then when you look to 2017, is it possible where -- it's a tale of 2 halves? Meaning that maybe some of the weakness you're seeing gets more impacted in the first half of the year and then you have a pickup in the second?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's 2 parts to that. Number one, I think your math it right but I'm not sure the logic is right. Lease termination revenue is part of our business, so we're making an active decision to take the cash now rather than just spread it out over subse
componenttext: Well, there's 2 parts to that. Number one, I think your math it right but I'm not sure the logic is right. Lease termination revenue is part of our business, so we're making an active decision to take the cash now rather than just spread it out over subsequent quarters. So although it causes lumpiness, we think it should be in the calculation same-center NOI at 5. It's not like street lighting or rent as fast as 1 41. They are noncash items. It's a business decision that leads to cash revenue, so that's why we factored in. I think next year, what we will see in the first half of the year is we'll be going against very tough comps in the first and second quarter because we still have the comparative benefit in 2016 of the expense cuts. So that may cause some of what you're referring to as a tale of 2 halves with the same-center NOI being higher in the second half of the year than the first.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: It was actually $78. Look, this is something we look at periodically. At this point in time, the best use of our capital is to put it back into our business. We're pleased with the program that we did. We announced it. We executed it. We're done with it and how to best use of our capital. And attention and focus is on our core business and reinvesting in our core business.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And could you maybe also comment on your relationship with Cadillac and GIC? And how do you -- because they are both partners and have been partners and also in your stock. Does that change the dynamics at all?
componenttext: Great. And could you maybe also comment on your relationship with Cadillac and GIC? And how do you -- because they are both partners and have been partners and also in your stock. Does that change the dynamics at all?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The relationship with each of them is very good, Different types of relationships. GIC has proven to be a very good partner. We see eye-to-eye in terms of the future of our real estate. Cadillac, obviously, we had a long-standing relationship with them fo
componenttext: The relationship with each of them is very good, Different types of relationships. GIC has proven to be a very good partner. We see eye-to-eye in terms of the future of our real estate. Cadillac, obviously, we had a long-standing relationship with them for over 20 years, and they've been a great operating partner also. So even if we don't have real estate and joint venture anymore, just because of the overall broad relationship, we continue to share best practices. We continue to share cross-border movement of tenants to the North and to the South. So that's a very productive and positive relationship, and Macerich Company is better for it.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So going to your kind of informal themes on the guidance for '17, what has specifically happened to, or embedded in that guidance, has to happen to either these spreads or kind of overall tenant sales productivity to the low end or high end?
componenttext: So going to your kind of informal themes on the guidance for '17, what has specifically happened to, or embedded in that guidance, has to happen to either these spreads or kind of overall tenant sales productivity to the low end or high end?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, the leasing spreads are pretty much dictated. I mean, we've got 3/4 of this year through and that's what really pushes the leasings -- the revenue that you recognized from releasing spreads. So really, it's a function of occupancy and whethe
componenttext: Well, I mean, the leasing spreads are pretty much dictated. I mean, we've got 3/4 of this year through and that's what really pushes the leasings -- the revenue that you recognized from releasing spreads. So really, it's a function of occupancy and whether there's occupancy fluctuation. We're able to lease subspace, such as the 4-story space we got back. We had 6 Sports Authorities that closed. And although it doesn't show up on the occupancy stats because that's an anchor, it's nonetheless got an economic impact. So if we refill some of that space sooner rather than later, that will have a positive impact on that range. That's probably the biggest variable.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And, I guess, the second question, I actually got my client in mind. Maybe it's not always about anchor store closures, but are you having any conversations with some of your anchors where they are asking to put more CapEx into a mall? Or maybe thin
componenttext: Okay. And, I guess, the second question, I actually got my client in mind. Maybe it's not always about anchor store closures, but are you having any conversations with some of your anchors where they are asking to put more CapEx into a mall? Or maybe things sooner that you'd like in a way for them to stay in the mall?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I actually have to laugh a little bit because the conversation is the flip of that. It's us talking to them because we're always ahead of them in terms of our forward thinking, in terms of keeping our malls up-to-date and reminding them of what we're
componenttext: No. I actually have to laugh a little bit because the conversation is the flip of that. It's us talking to them because we're always ahead of them in terms of our forward thinking, in terms of keeping our malls up-to-date and reminding them of what we're doing and suggesting to them that they join forces with us and update their store while we're updating the mall.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
