componenttext: And our final question comes from Christine McElroy with Citi map.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Michael Bilerman. I've been curious. If you think back over the last 18 months and that you executed in relation to your stock trading at a big discount to your NAV. Was selling assets, returning capital to shareholders through special dividends as w
componenttext: It's Michael Bilerman. I've been curious. If you think back over the last 18 months and that you executed in relation to your stock trading at a big discount to your NAV. Was selling assets, returning capital to shareholders through special dividends as well as share buybacks. Financing a lot and extending your maturities, lowering interest costs and then obviously focusing on margins. All the things that one would expect to drive stock. And as you were doing in your opening comments and talking about how the stocks are quite volatile since August, I guess then starting to think about well, what does that mean? Your stocks are at $70. What's the sort of honing in on in terms of frustration with that and what you could do? And I recognize you want to use all your excess capital to put within to your assets right now. But, I guess, as you start to think about furthering asset sales, or interest in asset sales or other means to arguably what is still a pretty large discount and take advantage of the volatility in the marketplace?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. I wish you would've ask me that question on August 1 when we were trading north of $91 a share. It would've been easier to answer. Today, look, we are not traders in our stock. We are -- we always, if anything, have had a very long
componenttext: That's a good question. I wish you would've ask me that question on August 1 when we were trading north of $91 a share. It would've been easier to answer. Today, look, we are not traders in our stock. We are -- we always, if anything, have had a very long view in terms of value creation. And we firmly believe that if we do the right thing by the real estate and we do the right thing in terms of our performance that, over time, we will be rewarded with a reasonable share price. And I think if you look back at our 21 histories or 21-year history as a public company, our total shareholder returns have reflected the fact that when you do good things at a real estate level and put up good results, you generate well above average, in our case, top quartile returns compared to the broader index. Let's not ignore the fact that we have -- we are in the bottom quartile as group. And then as a company this year, compared to all REITs, like I said to my comments, I feel all of your pain. We're doing what we can do to address the things that we can address, and we're trying to share our views on some of the things like Macy's store closures, occupancy cost, influence, releasing spreads, the health of the specialty store business. We try and address those for you so that you can see our views or maybe have another viewpoint. But look, it's a very fair question, but we are in this for the long haul. I think we're extremely well positioned, Michael, for the near and long term. And we're open to all ideas at all times, but the idea of training on our stock is not something that we find to be appealing at this point in time.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well,l I'm thinking about the public market investors are obviously more fickle. They can trade by the second. The private market investors, maybe you can share some of those conversations or whether they've expressed similar concerns about the fundamenta
componenttext: Well,l I'm thinking about the public market investors are obviously more fickle. They can trade by the second. The private market investors, maybe you can share some of those conversations or whether they've expressed similar concerns about the fundamentals. Have they perceived asset values? Because if you're not going to buy your stock, you certainly have the opportunity, which you've done creatively with  with GIC, in interest in assets to modify the, the public versus private market disconnect. Or maybe they  are concerned as a public market. I'm just trying to get a sense of where that sits.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Right. Let me define my answer for you. Thank you for clarifying the question. We think we have an extremely good pulse on the private market's view on our portfolio. Our sector and our company and, in particular, our properties. And we felt that it
componenttext: Okay. Right. Let me define my answer for you. Thank you for clarifying the question. We think we have an extremely good pulse on the private market's view on our portfolio. Our sector and our company and, in particular, our properties. And we felt that it was important a year ago to monetize that view and to show the rest all of you that, that was the way that we saw that private markets valued our assets. We felt at the time that there was a significant disconnect between the private market views in our company and the public markets views. The private markets views on our asset base have not changed. The -- if we were to go out today and talk about a similar pool of assets that we joint ventured, I would suspect that we'll be looking at a similar execution. But the discrepancy and the disparity and the percentage differential between the public market and the private market valuations of our company have arguably never been greater than they are today. So if that is true, it is a fact and we'll keep a post at it. In the meantime, what we need to do is to continue to earn the appreciation for our portfolio by increasing the income and the valuation of each of our assets, which is what we're doing. But the public market/private market disparity has probably, I can't remember what's been greater, but it's certainly very high today and much higher than it was a year ago.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And I guess part of the hesitation of selling more joint venture interest is you're encouraged by the potential growth and value as you invest in your assets. And while you good some of that spread today by selling your 50% interest, take Queens or
componenttext: Right. And I guess part of the hesitation of selling more joint venture interest is you're encouraged by the potential growth and value as you invest in your assets. And while you good some of that spread today by selling your 50% interest, take Queens or Kings or do something there, you lose a potential upside in terms of growth. And so you have this -- I guess your optionality or your options are a little bit more different now that spread. Does that make sense?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, my view is that it's a huge disparity. If we see a opportunity with a long-term view to deliver value to our shareholders by monetizing that disparity. It's something we have considered in the past as recently as a year ago. And we would consider i
componenttext:
Again, my view is that it's a huge disparity. If we see a opportunity with a long-term view to deliver value to our shareholders by monetizing that disparity. It's something we have considered in the past as recently as a year ago. And we would consider it in the future, but not today. 
All right. Well, listen. Thank you all for your participation. We look forward to seeing you at in a couple of weeks and on our tour on the day that Jean will announce. So thank you, and see you in a couple of weeks.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that concludes today's presentation. Thank you all for your participation, and you may now all disconnect.
componenttext: And that concludes today's presentation. Thank you all for your participation, and you may now all disconnect.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to The Macerich Company Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would like to remind you that this conference is being recorded. I would now like t
componenttext: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and thank you for standing by. Welcome to The Macerich Company Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would like to remind you that this conference is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Jean Wood, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thank you for joining us today on our third quarter 2016 earnings call. During the course of this call, management may make certain statements that may be deemed forward-looking within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities
componenttext:
Good morning. Thank you for joining us today on our third quarter 2016 earnings call. During the course of this call, management may make certain statements that may be deemed forward-looking within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. We refer you to today's press release and our SEC filings for a detailed discussion of forward-looking statements.
Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the earnings release and supplemental filed on Form 8-K with the SEC, which are posted in the Investors section of the company's website at www.macerich.com.
Joining us today are Art Coppola, CEO and Chairman; Tom O'Hern, Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; Robert Perlmutter, Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer; and John Perry, Senior Vice President, Investor Relations.
We look forward to seeing many of you at our investor event on Monday, November 14, in Phoenix in conjunction with the NAREIT conference. And with that, I will turn the call over to Tom.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jean. Consistent with past practice, we're going to be limiting this call to 1 hour. If we happen to run out of time and you still have questions, please don't hesitate to give me a call or John or Jean.The third quarter reflected continued s
componenttext:
Thank you, Jean. Consistent with past practice, we're going to be limiting this call to 1 hour. If we happen to run out of time and you still have questions, please don't hesitate to give me a call or John or Jean.
The third quarter reflected continued strong operating results as evidenced by the strength of most of our portfolio's key operating metrics. For the quarter, FFO was $1.04 per share, up from $1.01 in the third quarter of last year.
Same-center NOI increased by 4.2% compared to the third quarter of '15, which was a very tough comp quarter that was up 7%. This was positively impacted by $7.8 million of lease termination revenues in the third quarter. So in most cases, we were accelerating revenue we would have received in the fourth quarter and beyond into the third quarter.
Year-to-date, our same-center NOI growth is 6%. And as we discussed in our last earnings calls, most of the impact of the major tenant bankruptcies this year will be felt in the third and fourth quarter, which means lower same-center NOI growth in the third and fourth quarter than we saw in the first half of the year.
Our same-center estimate for NOI for the year, the range being tightened to 4.5 to 4.75. As we look forward into 2017, we're not giving full guidance for the year, but we are going to give some guidance on our expectation for same-center NOI growth. It will be down slightly from this year, and we expect the range of 3% to 4% same-center growth in 2017. Keep in mind that for the first half of 2016, we had the comparative benefit of the expense cuts that were initiated in the third quarter of '15. We will not have that comparative benefit as we compare 2017 to 2016.
Our gross operating margin on a same-center basis for the quarter improved to 69.6%. That was up from 68.5% in the third quarter of '15. And if we compare it to the third quarter of '14, 2 years ago, it's a 399-basis-point improvement.
Year-to-date, the same-center gross margin was 69.33%, up from 67.9% during the same period of last year. Bad debt expense was a modest 300,000 for the quarter, down compared to $800,000 in the third quarter of last year.
As I mentioned previously, lease termination fees were $7.8 million for the quarter. That compared to $3.4 million in the third quarter of last year. Most of these termination fees came from Sears and Kings Plaza, where we exercised our right to terminate their lease early. This had the effect of accelerating about $2.5 million of rent that would have been paid in the fourth quarter into the third.
During the third quarter, the average interest rate was 3.48%, up slightly from a year ago when it was 3.3%.
The balance sheet continues to be in great shape. At quarter end, our balance sheet metrics were healthy with debt-to-market cap at 37%, an interest coverage ratio of over 3.5x, debt-to-EBITDA on a forward basis of 7.2%, and the average debt maturity after the financing of Fresno Fashion Fair, which happened on October 6, is now over 6.5 years.
The financing market for high-quality regional malls remains good. A couple of examples. On October 6, we closed the $325 million loan on the previously unencumbered Fresno Fashion Fair. It was a CMBS loan, the first one we've done in a while, 10-year fixed-rate loan with an interest rate of 3.59%. The proceeds from that financing were used to pay down our line of credit, with subsequent to that paydown is approximately 100 -- or excuse me, $750 million outstanding.
Also on August 5, we closed on a $225 million loan on The Village at Corte Madera. That was a life insurance company loan. The term is 12 years and had a fixed interest rate of 3.5%.
I'm sure you saw in this morning's press release that we tightened our previous estimate of diluted FFO per share, and we narrowed the range to 4.05 to 4.10. That was down from 4.05 to 4.15. The revised FFO guidance comes primarily from reducing the midpoint of the range through the year on same-center NOI to 4.5 to 4.75. That is down from our original guidance range of 4.5 to 5.
The dilution from the sale of Capitola Mall, which was not included in the initial guidance, is offset by the gain on extinguishment of debt on Flagstaff, which also is not in the original guidance.
And now I'd like to turn it over to Bob to discuss the tenant environment.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Leasing activity during the third quarter was consistent with the first half of the year, producing strong releasing spreads and stable occupancies.Trailing 12-month leasing spreads were 16.1%. This is unchanged from the second quarter. Lea
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Leasing activity during the third quarter was consistent with the first half of the year, producing strong releasing spreads and stable occupancies.
Trailing 12-month leasing spreads were 16.1%. This is unchanged from the second quarter. Leasing spreads were relatively consistent through all of the regions.
Average rent for leases signed during the trailing 12-month period was $56.52.
During the third quarter, a total of 803,000 square feet of leases were signed, down slightly from the previous quarter. The average term for leases signed in the third quarter increased to 7 years.
Occupancy at the end of the third quarter was 95.3%. This represents a 30-basis-point increase on a quarter-over-quarter basis. Portfolio sales were $626 per square foot, and on a same-center basis, sales were up 1.3% year-over-year.
I'm going to talk a minute about development. The third quarter represented an important milestone for the company as the developments at Broadway Plaza and Green Acres Commons celebrated their official grand openings. These 2 projects are illustrative of the company's strong development skills, taking unique retail locations and extending their market dominance through densification. Combined, these 2 developments represented an investment of $263 million and will produce a blended stabilized return over 9%.
Over 10 years in the making, the expansion of Broadway Plaza began in 2012 when Neiman Marcus joined existing anchors Nordstrom and Macy's at the center. We are extremely pleased with the merchandise mix created at Broadway Plaza and, more importantly, the initial sales results from the tenants. The new space is 94% leased, and we anticipate all the retailers will be opened by this holiday season.
Green Acres Commons celebrated its grand opening on October 6. These 2-level power center anchored by Dick's Sporting Goods is a strong addition to the Green Acres retail campus and provides a home for many big box retailers looking to tap this attractive New York market.
There were also a number of important anchor openings in the portfolio. This served to further increase the draw out from these established retail centers.
At Fashion Outlets of Chicago, Nordstrom Rack opened its store on September 30. The center is now only 1 of 2 outlet venues in the U.S. that feature Nordstrom Rack, Saks OFF 5TH, Neiman's Last Call, Bloomingdale's outlet and Barney's as its anchors.
Dick's Sporting Goods opened a new store at The Oaks on October 11. In addition, 3 restaurants were added adjacent to Dick's. And finally, JCPenney had a very strong grand opening at Inland Center on October 21. The reception from the community was outstanding.
I'm going to take a minute to talk about tenant bankruptcies. There has been significant attention surrounding the health of certain specialty store tenants. You'll recall we entered 2016 cautious in our expectations regarding tenant bankruptcy. During the third quarter, the 3 most prominent bankruptcies of 2016 were resolved, albeit in very different fashions. First, the bankruptcy of Sports Authority resulted in the liquidation of the entire chain. Almost all the stores were closed except for a small number of leases purchased by other retailers. Second, PacSun completed their restructuring with the major creditor maintaining control of the company. PacSun emerged from bankruptcy in September with a restructured balance sheet and most of its store fleet intact. Finally, Aeropostale will emerge under the control of a consortium of buyers. It is anticipated that up to 500 stores will be retained.
Most of the economic impact from these bankruptcies will be felt during the fourth quarter of 2016 and into 2017. As Art has discussed in the past, throughout the portfolio, our focus is to reduce the exposure to weaker, lower productivity tenants well before they enter the restructuring process. For example, in 2012, Aeropostale had 45 stores in our portfolio. When they entered bankruptcy, this number had been reduced to 27. This was achieved through the disposition of lower productivity centers, replace tenant lease expiration with more productive tenants and early termination when the tenants still had the financial resources to pay termination fees. We expect our exposure with Aeropostale at the end of 2016 to be 19 store locations or approximately 78,000 square feet.
Looking forward, our leasing focus in the coming year will be to repurpose underproductive anchor department stores and replace the vacancy caused by recent tenant bankruptcies and early termination agreements. We believe opportunity exists in the anchor buildings by tapping demand from the big box and large format specialty retailers. As discussed on the last earnings call, the opportunity to retenant the Sears box at Kings Plaza with retailers that include Primark and Zara represents a unique opportunity to move the center to the next level in terms of traffic, sales productivity and merchandise mix.
And with that, I'll turn it over to Art.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bob, and thank you, Tom. Welcome to our call.As you can see from our numbers and our announcements, we had a very strong quarter. Our leasing spreads remained extremely strong, consistent with our belief that we have embedded growth within ou
componenttext:
Thank you, Bob, and thank you, Tom. Welcome to our call.
As you can see from our numbers and our announcements, we had a very strong quarter. Our leasing spreads remained extremely strong, consistent with our belief that we have embedded growth within our portfolio. We culminated an 18-month period of improving operating margins and achieved our goal of improving our operating margins by 400 basis points. And as Bob pointed out, during the quarter, we successfully completed on-time, on-budget and at the returns that were expected the Green Acres expansion and the Broadway Plaza expansion.
The Broadway Plaza expansion is an important one to contemplate. Broadway Plaza recently celebrated its 75th year in business, 75 years. We bought Broadway Plaza about 31 years ago, and at the time, it had an NOI of $3 million. Upon stabilization, we anticipate that NOI to be roughly $40 million. So this is testimony that great real estate in the hands of great management with a well-capitalized balance sheet can succeed in spite of any challenges to the retail environment and any changes to the retail environment.
Our future we see to be very strong and bright. I am pleased, however, in the context of concerns over the retail environment that at this point in time, with the completion of the Green Acres and the Broadway Plaza expansion, we have modest exposure in terms of our capital spend to a possible weak retail environment going forward over the near term. We only have Philadelphia and Kings Plaza in process, and both of those are proceeding as planned in terms of the merchandising and releasing.
Having said all of that, we feel the pain of our investors and those of you on this call that follow our company and our industry. Back on August 1, only a little less than 3 months ago, Macerich was trading at $91 a share and the RMZ was at $12.80. Today, we are roughly at $72 a share and the RMZ is down to $11.05. Malls as a sector are obviously down 500 to 600 basis points more than the other sectors that comprise the RMZ. It's the fundamentals about the mall business that has caused us to underperform. I would say from the viewpoint of our management that we see our fundamentals to be at least as strong today as we were 3 months ago, 6 months ago and 9 months ago. But it is hard to ignore the difference in terms of the performance of the sector.
If we're going to look at what event happened during the last 3 months that potentially led to, and has led to, this underperformance, it's hard to ignore the August 11 announcement by Macy's that they were closing 100 department stores. Many of our investors have expressed concern over this.
I want to share with you our view about those store closures. First of all, it is healthy for any retailer to prudently prune their portfolio and to weed out unproductive business units and to focus their attention on their more productive business units. That's what we do as a company. Closing stores is a prudent thing, and a stronger Macy's makes for a stronger mall base. As I look at our exposure to Macy's and to these closures, it's our understanding that when those closures are announced, that we will have one store in our portfolio at that point in time that will be on the closure list, and we see the closure of that store to be a positive, not a negative. It's most likely going to be a West L.A. store, and it's a situation that is ready for redevelopment as we've discussed in previous calls.
As I think further about department stores and I think about the anxiety that people have about department stores, I also think about what has happened over the past 10 or 12 years with department stores. And one of the seminal events that happened in the department store industry was in 2005, when Macy's bought May Company, and that caused a significant consolidation within the department store business. The combination of that event and the general underperformance of department stores over the last 10 or 12 years have actually been arguably a positive for mall owners. And I know that seems strange for me to say that, but let me share with you the reason why.
With the consolidation of Macy's and May Company going back 11 years ago, many of the brands that really make up the excitement within a department store began to look at the balance of power that they had under negotiations with department stores and decided that they wanted to add another channel of distribution to their omnichannel approach. Albeit 11 years ago, I doubt that word is really used that much. But many of the great brands have relied predominantly on their distribution to be wholesale distribution through the department stores. And over a period of time, those brands have decided to open up full-price retail stores and, in many cases, flagship stores. And they comprise many of the best names that we have in the mall today. Names like Kiehl's, Michael Kors, Eileen Fisher, HUGO BOSS, Diane von Furstenberg, AllSaints, LOUIS VUITTON, Tory Burch, Ted Baker, Armani, M.A.C. Cosmetics, Burberry, True Religion, the list goes on. And we see that trend continuing, which is a trend that, as I have mentioned in the past, is a trend that you see generally in place in the global portfolios of other owners of shopping centers around the world.
So we see the store closures of Macy's to be a positive, not a negative. We see its impact on Macerich to be a positive, not a negative. And as I look at the overall health of the department store business, let's not lose sight of the fact that it was only 3 years ago that many folks that probably are on this call right now felt that JCPenney was doomed in terms of their future. And at that point in time, we were bit of an outlier where we said, "Look, the one name that we see out there that we think is going to be in existence as a retailer 5 or 10 years after 2013 is going to be JCPenney." And there's been much written about their turnaround. I can tell you that JCPenney stores look better than ever, and we're very happy with the new Penney store that we just opened in Inland Center.
Again, I feel your pain. I understand it, and -- but the fundamentals that we have here remain very strong.
With that, I'd like to open it up for questions.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Christine McElroy with Citi.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Bobby, just following up on your releasing spreads, which have been pretty consistent in the last few quarters around that 14% to 16% level, and we know that doesn't include the rent adjustment. But just looking at your average base rent, your ABR grow
componenttext: So Bobby, just following up on your releasing spreads, which have been pretty consistent in the last few quarters around that 14% to 16% level, and we know that doesn't include the rent adjustment. But just looking at your average base rent, your ABR growth is pretty flattish over the last year. So realizing that those may be 2 different pools, but just wondering why with that sort of strength in spread, you're not seeing more flow through into ABR. Has that -- is that been impacted by the rent release at all? And with your comment that the biggest impact from the 3 bankruptcies should be in Q4 and 2017, how should we think about that trend in ABR over the next few quarters?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Christine, it has been flat over sort of -- if you look at the 2015 compared to the first 3 quarters of '16, it is somewhat 2 separate pools. So we have to be careful about that. But the -- where -- I think as a general rule, we continue to see strong gro
componenttext: Christine, it has been flat over sort of -- if you look at the 2015 compared to the first 3 quarters of '16, it is somewhat 2 separate pools. So we have to be careful about that. But the -- where -- I think as a general rule, we continue to see strong growth in the more dominant centers. We continue to see sort of moderate-to-weaker growth in the lesser productivity centers. And in terms of the impact of the lease amendments, we did run those numbers and the impact is not really material in our numbers. And what you need to remember is within the pool of these restructurings, some of the stores are closed, which obviously don't affect the spread. Some of the stores are assumed, which don't affect the spreads. So if you do look at your lease amendments, it's only the ones which you're modifying the lease which tend to be some percentage of the total leases but not 100%.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just, Art, just to follow up on your comment, do you think that these bankruptcies and sort of the granting of rent release and all this negative rhetoric around it could potentially translate into tougher lease negotiations in terms of nor
componenttext: Okay. And then just, Art, just to follow up on your comment, do you think that these bankruptcies and sort of the granting of rent release and all this negative rhetoric around it could potentially translate into tougher lease negotiations in terms of normal course leasings just from the perception that it creates?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. No. Demand remains very strong from a growing list of retailers. It's -- look, it's part of the process every year and always has been. So no, I don't see this having a secular impact on our position of strength in terms of lease negotiations.
componenttext: No. No. Demand remains very strong from a growing list of retailers. It's -- look, it's part of the process every year and always has been. So no, I don't see this having a secular impact on our position of strength in terms of lease negotiations.

componenttext: There's always the potential for change, but that's our best estimate right now. Those deals have been agreed to but are not yet documented, so that's in process. Just to understand part of the thinking on these processes is we look at what's in the long term best interest to these centers, and we believe very strongly in our real estate. And we don't necessarily solely focus on the short-term impact if we think it's the right long-term decision.

You noted your rather cautious view heading into '16, and I was just wondering if you can share your thoughts about how you feel late in the year here as we head into '17 about the leasing environment and additional store closures or bankruptcies in the year ahead.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I mentioned, I mean, our viewpoint through the entire year has been relatively consistent. We do feel like many of the circumstances that caused some of these bankruptcies are still present. We don't think it's gotten necessarily worse. We don't
componenttext: Well, as I mentioned, I mean, our viewpoint through the entire year has been relatively consistent. We do feel like many of the circumstances that caused some of these bankruptcies are still present. We don't think it's gotten necessarily worse. We don't think it's gotten materially better. So we continue to be cautious. We continue to try to be realistic, and we continue to try to make the right decisions long term for these properties.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then a question maybe, Art or Bob also. I was just wondering if you have a view over how the Aero process ultimately played out with the consortium that stepped in and what you're seeing with that process so far. Do you think we could see more o
componenttext: Okay. And then a question maybe, Art or Bob also. I was just wondering if you have a view over how the Aero process ultimately played out with the consortium that stepped in and what you're seeing with that process so far. Do you think we could see more of that going forward with other troubled retailers? And would Macerich look to potentially get involved?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I'm not going to comment on the future, but as it relates to the process, I think that I'm positive on the fact that Aero has a chance to potentially live another day. They have plenty of stores that were performing very well, and we'll see. So I gu
componenttext: Well, I'm not going to comment on the future, but as it relates to the process, I think that I'm positive on the fact that Aero has a chance to potentially live another day. They have plenty of stores that were performing very well, and we'll see. So I guess I'll indirectly say thank you to my friends at General Growth and Simon for being instrumental in that.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Jeremy Metz with UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Jeremy Metz with UBS.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of the margin improvement, you're about a year in, I think, a significant portion of the expense efficiencies are pretty well big to this point. So can you just talk a little bit more about the revenue side of it, where are you at today pushing s
componenttext: In terms of the margin improvement, you're about a year in, I think, a significant portion of the expense efficiencies are pretty well big to this point. So can you just talk a little bit more about the revenue side of it, where are you at today pushing some of those revenue enhancements? And how much more runway is there? Are we talking about maybe another 100 basis points of margin expansion in that 3% to 4% 2017 things to our expectation?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'm happy to take ownership of that. Look, without a lot of time to really calculate how much margin improvement we thought that we could obtain, we put out a goal of 400 basis points over a 2-year period. We announced that about 18 months ago, and
componenttext: Sure. I'm happy to take ownership of that. Look, without a lot of time to really calculate how much margin improvement we thought that we could obtain, we put out a goal of 400 basis points over a 2-year period. We announced that about 18 months ago, and we've achieved that in less than 2 years. I don't think there's greater -- that there's significantly more room for margin improvement from -- on the expense side, but we remain diligent about expenses at all times. I do believe that there is continued improvement on the revenue side, but I'm not going to put a target out there that we'll be held accountable for other than a promise that we'll report to you as time goes on, and my suspicion is that there's upside in that number. And that's certainly our goal, and we have plans, and we know how we're going to get there. But we'll report that as we go along.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. And then just as a follow-up here. Just given some of the pressures we had on the higher-end outlet space, does this impact in any of your thinking on Fashion Outlets of San Francisco at this point or still too early?
componenttext: All right. And then just as a follow-up here. Just given some of the pressures we had on the higher-end outlet space, does this impact in any of your thinking on Fashion Outlets of San Francisco at this point or still too early?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, it has not affected our thinking. But look, as I mentioned, there are anxieties out there in general coming from many different arenas. It's hard to ignore the headwinds that come from all kinds of different places, whether it be the strong dollar or
componenttext: No, it has not affected our thinking. But look, as I mentioned, there are anxieties out there in general coming from many different arenas. It's hard to ignore the headwinds that come from all kinds of different places, whether it be the strong dollar or the tourism spending reducing, whatever the anxieties are. And so as I mentioned in my comments, I think we are pleased to have a modest capital spend in place. We're in good shape at this point in time in terms of our marketing and leasing of the 2 projects that we're spending money on, Kings and Philadelphia. And we have the ability on -- in anything else that we do in the future to time the shovel in the ground to sign leases.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Craig Schmidt with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Craig Schmidt with Bank of America.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Nice to hear the good news you're only having one Macy's closed out of yours. However, starting to look like the REITs in general will not have as many closings as other private malls. But what do you think might happen to some of those lower-quality priv
componenttext: Nice to hear the good news you're only having one Macy's closed out of yours. However, starting to look like the REITs in general will not have as many closings as other private malls. But what do you think might happen to some of those lower-quality private malls as they lose the Macy's and their ability to remain viable?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The good news is I don't have to spend time thinking about that, and I don't have an answer for you right off the top of my head. We made a decision. The flip side of that is that, look, it's not surprising that the public companies which tend to own the
componenttext: The good news is I don't have to spend time thinking about that, and I don't have an answer for you right off the top of my head. We made a decision. The flip side of that is that, look, it's not surprising that the public companies which tend to own the better properties have lesser exposure. It's not surprising that Macerich, which has been extremely diligent in pruning our portfolio, has even less exposure than you would expect. So we see -- look, we see it as healthy for Macy's. Here's the flip side though also. If Macy's had, like, ignored the idea of pruning their portfolio, I think the latter commentary should be why aren't they closing stores? So here they come out and they decide to be prudent and smart in running their business, and all of a sudden -- I understand it. Look, it came out of kind of left field for a lot of people. We kind of thought, "Well, God, I thought Macy's was okay." But it was -- it's good for their business, and what's good for them is good for us. And whether it be Macy's or any other anchor that we have in the portfolio that we own, we see it as opportunities generally. We see the opportunities to replace them with other uses that draw traffic and that do the job of what an anchor is supposed to do. So from my viewpoint, I don't see that's a negative at all.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just has there been any forward progress in terms of Fashion Outlets of Philadelphia, some of maybe the bigger space getting taken up?
componenttext: Okay. And then just has there been any forward progress in terms of Fashion Outlets of Philadelphia, some of maybe the bigger space getting taken up?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And announcements will be made as leases are signed and as we deem it appropriate in terms of the marketing of the property. But we just had an all-day session with our leasing team on that project yesterday, and we're in good shape at this point in
componenttext: Yes. And announcements will be made as leases are signed and as we deem it appropriate in terms of the marketing of the property. But we just had an all-day session with our leasing team on that project yesterday, and we're in good shape at this point in time.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Michael Mueller with JPMorgan.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Tom, the 3% to 4% same-store NOI for 2017, is that being impacted significantly at all by a change in some lease term expectations compared to what you're booking in 2016?
componenttext: So Tom, the 3% to 4% same-store NOI for 2017, is that being impacted significantly at all by a change in some lease term expectations compared to what you're booking in 2016?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we haven't gotten down to that level of disclosure on the guidance. But at $19 million for 2016, that's extraordinarily high for us. I mean, we've been averaging 10% to 12%. That's always a trade-off when you take that termination. For example, we m
componenttext: Well, we haven't gotten down to that level of disclosure on the guidance. But at $19 million for 2016, that's extraordinarily high for us. I mean, we've been averaging 10% to 12%. That's always a trade-off when you take that termination. For example, we made the decision to terminate Sears early because you're foregoing future minimum rent and charges. I mean, it is factored into our thinking in general that we will not have lease term revenue that's as high as we got this year.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. And then looking at a couple of your top centers. So Queens Center sale the past couple of years have been about $1,100 a foot. This year, it looks like you're over $1,300. And then Washington Square, where they were $1,100 a foot for the pa
componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then looking at a couple of your top centers. So Queens Center sale the past couple of years have been about $1,100 a foot. This year, it looks like you're over $1,300. And then Washington Square, where they were $1,100 a foot for the past couple of years, it's down to about $1,000. I was wondering if there's anything specifically going on at those 2 centers or just put a bit of color.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Bob Perlmutter. The Queens had a Apple Store that annualized and was brought into the pool. So that impacted the sales per square foot. And Washington Square is a no-sales tax state, so we actually had the opposite in terms of some of the com
componenttext: Yes. This is Bob Perlmutter. The Queens had a Apple Store that annualized and was brought into the pool. So that impacted the sales per square foot. And Washington Square is a no-sales tax state, so we actually had the opposite in terms of some of the commercial sales being transferred out of the retail store into other venues.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next we have Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Next we have Alexander Goldfarb with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe, Tom, just some quick guidance questions, and then I'll go to maybe Bobby. But first, in the guidance, some of the changes that we noted were the impact of asset sales from last year and earlier this year, now expected to be $80 million versus $75 m
componenttext: Maybe, Tom, just some quick guidance questions, and then I'll go to maybe Bobby. But first, in the guidance, some of the changes that we noted were the impact of asset sales from last year and earlier this year, now expected to be $80 million versus $75 million. And then the debt gain impact also changed. It went from, I think, a negative sort of down 2 to positive plus 4.5. Can you just walk us through what happened from second quarter when you provided the guidance to now, what changed in that?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And you may have missed it, Alex. I think we already talked about this earlier in the call, but there's really 2 things. We sold Capitola, which happened in the second quarter. Obviously, we knew about that, but we are not about to knee jerk react an
componenttext: Yes. And you may have missed it, Alex. I think we already talked about this earlier in the call, but there's really 2 things. We sold Capitola, which happened in the second quarter. Obviously, we knew about that, but we are not about to knee jerk react and change guidance just for that one item because we're also in negotiations with the loan servicer on Flagstaff for that asset to go back. And we knew when that ultimately happened and title was transferred, we'd recognize a gain, and those 2 roughly offsetting. So it certainly didn't warrant us changing guidance down for Capitola and then turning around the next quarter and moving it up for Flagstaff. So those 2 netted out.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay. Then that's helpful. And then second is on the street retail versus the malls. Here in New York, you obviously got Kings and Queens that would presumably compete with some of the street retail locations. And in Chicago, you have 500 North Mich
componenttext: Okay. Okay. Then that's helpful. And then second is on the street retail versus the malls. Here in New York, you obviously got Kings and Queens that would presumably compete with some of the street retail locations. And in Chicago, you have 500 North Michigan that's on the avenue as well as in line. Have you noticed a change in the way that retailers as you talk to them, as they're viewing their street retail presence versus the mall presence? My point is do the retailers think of those in concert? Or do they think of each as different, and the street retail is a different leasing decision than the mall retail? Or within a certain metro or submarket, they view it together, and it's just basically where they think they can get more traffic?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alex, it's Bob Perlmutter. I would say they really view it different -- I mean, a couple of distinctions. Kings and Queens really don't compete with the street retail in Manhattan or New York. It's a more traditional mall mix, and their strength really co
componenttext: Alex, it's Bob Perlmutter. I would say they really view it different -- I mean, a couple of distinctions. Kings and Queens really don't compete with the street retail in Manhattan or New York. It's a more traditional mall mix, and their strength really comes from the density of the population and the lack of alternatives for these retailers. North Bridge has a little bit of both. It has both sort of the traditional mall space as well as some street space. Generally, there's a pretty big distinction between what the retailers are trying to achieve on the street of these flagship locations or inside the mall. So they tend to be different decisions. And often, the real estate decision is controlled by different people within the retailer. So there's not really a situation where somebody says, "I'm going to -- the street market is getting soft. I'm going to put more resources into the mall," or vice versa. They're really, in our mind, 2 independent decisions.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Tayo Okusanya with Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Tayo Okusanya with Jefferies.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is George on for Tayo. Just a question on Fashion Outlets of Philadelphia. So are you running into any issues on the leasing front with radius restrictions?
componenttext: This is George on for Tayo. Just a question on Fashion Outlets of Philadelphia. So are you running into any issues on the leasing front with radius restrictions?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sure that we run into those everywhere, but nothing that is getting in the way of us delivering a very good project.
componenttext: I'm sure that we run into those everywhere, but nothing that is getting in the way of us delivering a very good project.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Morgan with Canaccord Genuity.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Morgan with Canaccord Genuity.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just trying to kind of triangulate the various numbers. If I take where your guidance is now for this year, you did about 7 in the first half of the year and 4 this quarter. So that would put you, I guess, around 1 or so in the fourth quarter. And I k
componenttext: I'm just trying to kind of triangulate the various numbers. If I take where your guidance is now for this year, you did about 7 in the first half of the year and 4 this quarter. So that would put you, I guess, around 1 or so in the fourth quarter. And I know that's -- some of that's due to the lease term income, it sounds like. But if the back half is in kind of in the 2 to 3 range, it sounds like there's some kind of movement higher as you look into next year. I mean, is there anything kind of I'm getting wrong? Or if there is some movement higher, kind of what would that be due to?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you've got a number of things impacting the fourth quarter. We've accelerated some rents, Sears for example at Kings Plaza, and pushed that into the third quarter. Normally, it would have been in the fourth, which is fairly sizeable. That wa
componenttext: Well, I think you've got a number of things impacting the fourth quarter. We've accelerated some rents, Sears for example at Kings Plaza, and pushed that into the third quarter. Normally, it would have been in the fourth, which is fairly sizeable. That was about $3 million in rent that got moved. Also, we're going against very tough comps in the third and fourth quarter because we had the benefit of the expense cuts in the third and fourth quarter on a comp basis last year compared to this year, and that won't be recurring. So we see next year being a fairly normal year. We're wrestling through the final aspects of some of the bankruptcies from this year. But really, our same-center growth is driven by rent increases, which in general tend to be 2.5% to 3% in a given year. And generally, we look at these things at an occupancy-neutral basis. And so I think fourth quarter was pretty unusual, and we don't think it's indicative of what next year will be like. And that's why we gave the guidance for next year.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I guess it's kind of safe to say that you don't see anybody in terms of watch list for like kind of first quarter, post-holiday bankruptcies?
componenttext: And I guess it's kind of safe to say that you don't see anybody in terms of watch list for like kind of first quarter, post-holiday bankruptcies?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I defer to Bob on this.
componenttext: I defer to Bob on this.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of specific names, no. But again, we do maintain a watch list, and there are certain tenants that we're looking to reduce our exposure to.
componenttext: In terms of specific names, no. But again, we do maintain a watch list, and there are certain tenants that we're looking to reduce our exposure to.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My just last question on Macy's. That's good color there, too. Macy's, in addition to kind of culling the bottom of the portfolio, mentioned that they might try to, like they did this year, take a couple of opportunistic closings at malls where ther
componenttext: Okay. My just last question on Macy's. That's good color there, too. Macy's, in addition to kind of culling the bottom of the portfolio, mentioned that they might try to, like they did this year, take a couple of opportunistic closings at malls where there's a higher and better use. And I'm just wondering, in your portfolio, say, that you've got a handful of malls where there's more than one Macy's and stronger assets. I mean, is there something you would look to potentially recapture? Is your appetite for recapturing department store space changed at all now, given your kind of view of the leasing environment? Or is that still something you'd look to do?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I do think that -- thanks for the question. I do think that the one store closure that we're anticipating fits exactly into that category that there's a higher and better use and a user that's willing to pay them a compelling number to convert their
componenttext: Well, I do think that -- thanks for the question. I do think that the one store closure that we're anticipating fits exactly into that category that there's a higher and better use and a user that's willing to pay them a compelling number to convert their store to a higher and better use. And they've deemed it to -- they look at their overall representation and deemed that to be appropriate for them. And we see it as potentially an opportunity for us. As we look at the rest of the stores that we have with Macy's, there are opportunities in certain locations to repurpose either some of their square footage, downsize them or maybe even completely replace them with a higher and better use. We're in conversations with them. This is going to be, I think, a longer conversation. I wouldn't predict that there will be any announcements from us on this anytime soon, but I would predict there will be announcements that would fit the category of converting some of their square footage in a location or all of their square footage in a location to a higher and better use that should happen sometime in the future. I also would anticipate that there will be announcements in the future where we and Macy's have worked together to just make the overall environment more profitable, and that could involve something that could be a monetization for them, too.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Richard Hill with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from Richard Hill with Morgan Stanley.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ronald Kamdem on Richard Hill's line. Just 2 quick ones for me. The first is on kind of the financing market. I know you guys got Fresno done in the CMBS side. Just maybe give us a little color on what you're seeing out there and if Eastland is st
componenttext: This is Ronald Kamdem on Richard Hill's line. Just 2 quick ones for me. The first is on kind of the financing market. I know you guys got Fresno done in the CMBS side. Just maybe give us a little color on what you're seeing out there and if Eastland is still a potential funding -- financing you're trying to get done for this year.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Eastland is an unencumbered asset, and it's available for financing. We haven't started that process yet, but it's certainly possible. We had good experience at Fresno. We exposed that to the CMBS market. The pricing, as you probably heard, at 359 f
componenttext: Well, Eastland is an unencumbered asset, and it's available for financing. We haven't started that process yet, but it's certainly possible. We had good experience at Fresno. We exposed that to the CMBS market. The pricing, as you probably heard, at 359 for a 10-year deal, was fairly competitive. I would say it was -- would have been very competitive with a life company have we gone that route. And I don't know how deep the market is. We were just really trying to finance that one particular asset, but I will tell you it was very competitive, and there were probably 5 or 6 investment banks that stepped up with some pretty competitive quotes on that 10-year fixed rate deal.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And the only other thing I would add to that is that look, regional malls remain one of the most attractive asset categories for lenders to place long term fixed-rate mortgages on.
componenttext: Yes. And the only other thing I would add to that is that look, regional malls remain one of the most attractive asset categories for lenders to place long term fixed-rate mortgages on.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just going back to kind of the same-store NOI. One, if I back out the lease termination fees, my quick math is showing 2.1% growth for the quarter, one, is that right? And then when you look to 2017, is it possible where it's a tale of 2 h
componenttext: Great. And then just going back to kind of the same-store NOI. One, if I back out the lease termination fees, my quick math is showing 2.1% growth for the quarter, one, is that right? And then when you look to 2017, is it possible where it's a tale of 2 halves? Meaning that maybe some of the weakness you're seeing gets more impacted in the first half of the year and then you have a pickup in the second?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's 2 parts to that. Number one, I think your math is right, but I'm not sure the logic is right. Lease termination revenue is part of our business, so we're making an active decision to take the cash now rather than just spread it out over subs
componenttext: Well, there's 2 parts to that. Number one, I think your math is right, but I'm not sure the logic is right. Lease termination revenue is part of our business, so we're making an active decision to take the cash now rather than just spread it out over subsequent quarters. So although it causes lumpiness, we think it should be in the calculation of same-center NOI. It's not like street lending or rent [indiscernible] 141 that are noncash items. It's a business decision that leads to cash revenue, so that's why we factored in. I think next year, what we will see in the first half of the year is we'll be going against very tough comps in the first and second quarter because we still have the comparative benefit in 2016 of the expense cuts. So that may cause some of what you're referring to as a tale of 2 halves with the same-center NOI being higher in the second half of the year than the first.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Floris van Dijkum with Boenning.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Floris van Dijkum with Boenning.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016

componenttext: A quick question for Art maybe. If you could comment on your view towards share buyback at the moment.

componenttextpreview: We've completed our program. Nothing else is on our radar screen.
componenttext: We've completed our program. Nothing else is on our radar screen.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So despite the fact that I think your average share buyback was around $80, if I'm not mistaken. Even though the share price is low, you wouldn't contemplate buying back more stock at the moment?
componenttext: So despite the fact that I think your average share buyback was around $80, if I'm not mistaken. Even though the share price is low, you wouldn't contemplate buying back more stock at the moment?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It was actually $78. Look, this is something we look at periodically. At this point in time, the best use of our capital is to put it back into our business. We're pleased with the program that we did. We announced it. We executed it. We're done with it,
componenttext: It was actually $78. Look, this is something we look at periodically. At this point in time, the best use of our capital is to put it back into our business. We're pleased with the program that we did. We announced it. We executed it. We're done with it, and now the best use of our capital and attention and focus is on our core business and reinvesting in our core business.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And could you maybe also comment on your relationship with Cadillac and GIC? And how are you -- because they're both partners -- have been partners in assets and also in your stock, did that change the dynamics at all?
componenttext: Great. And could you maybe also comment on your relationship with Cadillac and GIC? And how are you -- because they're both partners -- have been partners in assets and also in your stock, did that change the dynamics at all?

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The relationship with each of them is very good, different types of relationships. GIC has proven to be a very good partner. We see eye-to-eye in terms of the future of our real estate. Cadillac, obviously, we had a long-standing relationship with them fo
componenttext: The relationship with each of them is very good, different types of relationships. GIC has proven to be a very good partner. We see eye-to-eye in terms of the future of our real estate. Cadillac, obviously, we had a long-standing relationship with them for over 20 years, and they've been a great operating partner also. So even if we don't have real estate in joint venture anymore, just because of the overall broad relationship, we continue to share best practices. We continue to share cross-border movement of tenants to the north and to the south. So that's a very productive and positive relationship, and The Macerich Company is better for it.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Ki Bin Kim with SunTrust.

headline: The Macerich Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2016
